bibl.title: Belasco, David. The charity ball; a comedy drama in four acts

castList.head: CHARACTERS
castList.castItem: John Van Buren , rector of St. Mildred's
Dick Van Buren , firm of Van Buren &.mp; Creighton, Wall Street, known on the street as "The Earthquake"
Alec Robinson , ambitious to be dubbed on change "Alexander the Great"
Judge Peter Gurney Knox , left over from a past era, unable to catch up with the present
Franklin Cruger , the king of Wall Street
Mr. Creighton , junior partner of Van Buren &.mp; Creighton
Mr. Betts , the organist of St. Mildred's
Paxton , confidential clerk of Van Buren &.mp; Creighton
Cain , "A thing of shreds and patches"
Ann Cruger , a New York girl
Phyllis Lee , in love with Dick
Mrs. Camilla De Peyster , who dabbles in stocks
Bess Van Buren , tired of dolls, ready for beaux
Mrs. Van Buren , the rector's mother

div.head: ACT I.
div.stage: Scene : The sitting room at the rectory, Christmas day, 1887. For arrangement, see diagram. Children laugh at rise, off L. Music .
Discovered : Mrs. Van Buren standing on steps, R.U.E., listening. She is an elderly woman, white-haired. She is blind but moves easily about the room, always cheerful. Stop music .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p:
The parish buildings are a perfect pandemonium!
[ Sophie enters, R.U.E., down the steps, laden with a large box of toys, and comes down, R.C. ]
How happy those children are over their Christmas dinner. Sophie, have you any toys?

sp.speaker: Sophie .
sp.p: A few of them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p:
Dolls for the girls and marbles and bats for the boys, and oh, dear! Those horrible tin horns. What would an American boy be without his tin horn!
[ Laughs. Bess enters, L.U.E., sees her mother, runs quickly and stands with uplifted face. Laugh outside. Exit Sophie, L.U.E. ]
Child laughter is like an echo from another world, Bess!
[ Drawing Bess close to her ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: Pressing her cheek against her Mother's ]
sp.p:
Angel!
[ Going quickly up, C., and looking off, L.2.E. ]
Dinner's over, and Ann is giving out the presents. My! How my heart's thumping.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Alec's coming to take all the children.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.stage: Sitting on sofa, R., and weaving basket which she finds on stand, R.
sp.p: Take them? Where?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Take their photographs, angel. He told me this morning he'd come.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Did you see him this morning?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: I see him every morning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Bess!

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Accident.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Every morning?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: Coming to back of sofa, R.
sp.p: Nothing more natural. As I go up Madison Avenue to school, he comes down Madison Avenue to business.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Does he walk all the way to Wall Street?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: Coming around and half sitting on sofa on L. of Mrs. Van Buren
sp.p:
Oh, dear, no! He turns back and carries my books for me to Sixty-seventh
Street and then takes the elevated. Brother John caught us one morning. He knows we are sweethearts!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Sweethearts! What do you and Alec find to talk about?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Lots of things! He's in Mr. Franklin Cruger's office, studying for a stock broker. He hadn't been there a month before Mr. Cruger told him he knew more about the business than he did.
[ Rising, going up on platform, R.C., at back ]
You ought to hear him give quotations!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Poetry?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
No, stock, angel. Why doesn't Alec come?
[ Looking ]
The children are just dying to have their pictures taken.

sp.speaker: Betts .
sp.l: If a body meet a body
If a body kiss a body,

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p:
I do love to hear Mr. Betts dip into the grab basket of old songs and bring out the first he happens to get hold of.
[ Betts enters, R.U.E. He is a man about fifty with long white hair, strong characteristic face, the embodiment of joviality. His clothes a trifle eccentric, not exaggerated. He carries a cloak on his arm and a very large umbrella. As he sees Mrs. Van Buren and Bess, he ends in a chuckle ]

sp.speaker: Betts .
sp.p: Miss Lee is in the reception room.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Miss Lee?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Did you have any trouble in finding her?

sp.speaker: Betts .
sp.p:
Not after Mr. Van Buren's description — "a sad, pale-faced girl" — Her face made me think of —
[ Hums ]
"The heart bowed down by" — ahem! Shall I bring the young lady here?
[ Bess goes to hassock, R. of small stand, R. ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p:
If you please.
[ Exit Betts, R.U.E., humming air "The Girl I left behind me" ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: Who has seated herself on hassock, R. of stand, R., and opening album
sp.p: If she is half as pretty as her photograph here — who is Phyllis Lee?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: A young girl whom your brother John met during his visit to Florida. As she was coming to New York and a total stranger here, he asked me to invite her to remain with us for a time.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Isn't that like brother John?
[ Music; plaintive till Phyllis is well on. Phyllis Lee appears at back from R.U.E., in travelling dress. She is almost timid in manner. She is preceded by Betts who sees that she is not coming, turns and beckons to her ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Always by the side of misery, lifting from despair many a poor creature whose first happiness was his help and friendship.

sp.speaker: Betts .
sp.p:
Go to her. She can't see.
[ Aloud ]
Mrs. Van Buren.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p:
Oh!
[ Putting out her left hand ]
This is Phyllis Lee.
[ Phyllis comes down and takes her hand; Betts crosses, L., and exit, L.U.E. ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: Around back to L. of her and seizing her L. hand
sp.p: Oh! I'm awfully glad to see you.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Madam — Miss Van Buren —

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Call me Bess.
[ Kisses her ]

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: I overheard your words, Mrs. Van Buren. Even you do not know what his help means.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Well, if you like brother John so much, I wonder what you will think of Dick.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: She thinks there is nobody like her brother Dick.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Except brother John. But I must say Dick gives more presents. In his last letter from Paris he promised me a great surprise.
[ Bess going L. of table, C. ]

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: He is in Europe?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Yes. He has devoted himself so persistently to business it has affected his health.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Not seriously, I hope.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p:
Unless the Umbria brings a letter today, I shall feel worried.
[ Phyllis slightly overcome, supports herself on table, C. ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: Crossing to her, back of table ]
sp.p: Why, what's the matter, Miss Lee?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: You must be worn out. Bess will take you to your room.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p:
Thank you.
[ Music ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Come along, Phyllis. You don't mind my calling you Phyllis, do you?
[ Crossing with Phyllis upstairs, R.3.E., and off, R., chatting ]
You see when two girls meet and like each other right away, the sooner they become acquainted with each other the better. I'm awfully anxious for you to meet Alec Robinson. He's one of the nicest fellows in New York.
[ Mrs. Van Buren sits on sofa, takes up basket and commences to weave. During latter part of last speech, Mrs. De Peyster is heard speaking outside, R. ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p:
In here. Oh, thanks, I'll find her.
[ Enter Mrs. De Peyster, R.U.E. She is prepossessing in appearance, dressed in latest fashion. Her manner is brisk and matter-of-fact. Coming down to Mrs. Van Buren ]
Good morning, dear, good morning. I think after such a busy day's work, I may take a half holiday.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Ah, Camilla!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: I rushed away after service this morning. You see during the second lesson, Mrs. Homer G. Putnam said to me — her pew is next to ours, you know — that if I held any shares in the Consolidated Gas Tank Co. to get rid of them at once. I had a thousand! I don't know what in the world John preached about this morning. I had tanks on the brain. Just imagine my anxiety. Being Christmas day, of course, my broker would not be downtown! I sent messengers flying in every direction. And where do you think we found him? In a Turkish bath spending his Christmas. But by twelve o'clock tomorrow morning someone else will be asphyxiated with my gas.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Back from Europe only three days and already deep in speculation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p:
Oh, my dear! I've kept my feelings bottled up so long that the moment I landed, out popped the cork.
[ Rises ]
Oh, by the way, how well Judge Knox is looking. I saw him at Daly's last night. He bowed and smiled. I beckoned to him with my fan but he shook his head. Do you think anything could have induced him to move from that orchestra chair? Not a bit of it! I once said to him, "How is it, judge, I never see you go out between the acts?" He replied, dear old-fashioned fellow, "Madam, though I am not a camel, I provide myself for the entire evening."
[ Sitting on chair by table ]
While I was abroad, I received a letter from him with these words — "When next we meet prepare to be astounded." Now what do you think he means?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: It isn't very hard to guess.

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: For the past six months we have heard nothing from Judge Knox — but, "Mrs. De Peyster" — "When did you hear from her?" — "Is she well?" — "When will she return?"

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p:
Really.
[ Crossing to sofa ]
What else did he say?
[ Alec enters, R.C., carrying photographic apparatus, his manner that of a boy verging toward manhood. Mrs. De Peyster crosses to L. ]

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.stage: Putting two packages on floor and leaning tripod against column, C. Going down, L., to Mrs. De Peyster
sp.p:
Auntie, got three cents for the messenger? I'm just that much short. How do, Mrs. Van Buren.
[ Going to her and taking her hand ]
Now, Aunt Camilla, don't be all day. These messengers charge by the second. It'll be four cents before you get it out and five before I can get to him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.stage: Who has opened her purse and taken out bill
sp.p: Oh, I have nothing hut five-dollar bills.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: That will do very nicely, thank you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.stage: Feeling in purse and taking out three pennies
sp.p: I have some pennies here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: That will do better.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.stage: Crossing to Mrs. Van Buren and taking pennies
sp.p: Mrs. Van Buren, never do that again. I am just four dollars and ninety-seven cents out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Whatever that boy does with all the money he gets —

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: All I get! Six dollars a week salary, and fifteen, allowance. If I didn't invest a little in Wall Street, I wouldn't have enough to keep me in neckties!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Alec, do you speculate?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
Well, I'm not in Franklin Cruger's office for nothing.
[ Enter Bess downstairs, R.3.E., and unseen by Alec comes slowly down, R., watching Alec to L. of sofa, R. ]
At first I was a little bit dizzy at the way he'd wipe up the street about once a week. But I didn't lose a point. Every time he took a flyer, I flew with him. Every time he dropped, I went clean out of sight. I was with him, though. Oh, wait till I'm called "Alexander the Great." Auntie, you'll be proud of me yet.
[ Warn music ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Oh, angel, isn't he smart?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Hello, Bess.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Hello, Alec.
[ Children heard, off L. ]

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
Come help me untie this camera.
[ They go upstage and unwrap camera. Music, medium lively, pianissimo, and swell at Ann's entrance ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Now, now, be patient and I'll read you a story.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: There's Ann Cruger.

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Ann here?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: She has been giving a dinner to the poor children of the parish. She's been hard at work since eight o'clock this morning.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Look at that little mite of a fellow holding on to her. They won't let her go.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Run back, little fellow; I'll not be long.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: What should we do without our Ann Cruger?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Merry Christmas!

sp.speaker: Omnes .
sp.p:
Merry Christmas, etc.
[ Bess up to Alec, C. Music swells. Enter Ann, L.2.E. She has on a pretty white apron over her fashionable walking dress ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
Listen! Do you hear that laughing, romping babble of glee? Doesn't it make the blood rush through your veins and knock at your heart until you want to take up their baby world in your arms and hug it?
[ Crossing to R. table back of sofa ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p:
Ann, anybody would think you were one of them.
[ Coming down ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
I am. Oh, what a glorious day! On the stroke of two, the doors were thrown open. In rushed a hundred ragged little boys and girls. It would have done your heart good to have seen the awe come over them at the sight of the tables. When they were convinced it was not a dream but all real — oh, the grin! You could have heard it.
[ All laugh ]
Just then a tiny tot with screams of delight dashed head over heels for the table, climbed up in his chair and yelled, "I've beat the whole gang o' yer!"
[ All laugh ]
Just think of these pale, pinched faces, with hungry eyes and open mouths, waiting for their struggles with the Turks. I gave the command. With a yell that would have done credit to a Comanche tribe, they took their places and the attack began. O Raphael, your two little fat cherubs with their angel wings are not to be compared with my lean waifs and their turkey wings.
[ All laugh ]
Then came the dessert. I didn't know where they were going to put that, but they must have been made at the Goodyear Rubber Factory!
[ Goes R. and embraces Mrs. Van Buren; Mrs. De Peyster, L. ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: They didn't even wail to say "Amen" after grace.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Perhaps, like Macbeth, Amen stuck in their throats.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.stage: Crosses in front and up, L. Going up into alcove, L., and looking for book
sp.p: But where did I leave my story book?

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Ann, don't you think my trip abroad has done me good? Why have you given up spending your summers in Europe?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.stage: Crossing R. at C. of stage, still looking for book on piano, R.
sp.p:
Looking at ruins becomes rather monotonous after four summers. Besides, what have you got there that we haven't got here except London fogs and you get those from us. I'm an American and like novelty. That's why I prefer the new world — Europe after America. As I take European cheese, after an American dinner.
[ Crosses, L. ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Ah, you should have been with me on the Rhine, through Switzerland.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: I went up the Hudson around the Horse Shoe curve. I stood on the summit of Pike's Peak.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: What's the matter with Hoboken Heights?

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Alec.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
I forgot the messenger.
[ Exit C.R., precipitately ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p:
You must not rouse Ann's patriotic spirit.
[ Rises, to C. ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
But where did I leave my story book? I must run back.
[ Goes out, R.U.E., looking for story book ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p:
I'll go, too, dear. I shouldn't be able to sit in my pew Sunday if I didn't do something for charity. I'll have a look at them.
[ To Mrs. Van Buren ]
Oh, will you come, dear?
[ Exeunt Mrs. Van Buren and Mrs. De Peyster, L.2.E. ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
Ah, here it is. Gulliver's Travels .
[ Starts to go, L. ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: L.C. Coming down quickly, detaining Ann ]
sp.p: Ann, I want to ask you something before Alec comes back.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Well, be quick, Bess. I haven't a moment to spare.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Ann, how does a girl feel when she's in love?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
Really, Bess, we haven't time by four hours to discuss that subject. You shall spend the night with me and well talk about it from bedtime to morning. I must go, dear —
[ Starts ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: Holding her dress and still detaining her
sp.p:
But you go to sleep as soon as your head touches the pillow and leave me awake to think all night.
[ Drawing away from her with comic pantomime ]
Is it — er — a sort — of — of a — a general feeling — all over you? You know.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: I do not know.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Oh, yes, you do.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Bess —

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: I know why you gave this dinner to brother John's waifs. Just because — you knew — it would please — him.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.stage: Half shocked, then smiles, then speaks ]
sp.p:
Serves me right for stopping to hear a child's prattle about love.
[ Starting to go, L. ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Well, I know brother John's symptoms.
[ Ann pauses on threshold, showing interest ]
Oh, don't let me keep you!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Has brother John — any symptoms?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Um-um. Want to know?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
Yes.
[ Crossing to L.C. ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Then, will you keep awake tonight?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Yes — yes.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
You're not anxious, are you? Well —
[ Confidentially ]
I heard brother John tell angel that he didn't know what he would do without you — that he had in his heart such a feeling for you —
[ Ann, whose arm is about Bess, presses her close to her. Bess disengages herself and throws herself on floor at Ann's feet in front of her ]
If you squeeze me so tight, I can't tell you. Do you think you could love brother John enough to be his wife?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
I think — that — you can't keep a secret.
[ Drawing Bess to her inpulsively, kisses her ]
There!
[ Runs off, L.U.E. Bess to R. Reenter Alec, C.R. ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Oh, she knows the symptoms all right.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.stage: Coming down, C., with camera which he places C. Bess helps him. Then crosses to L.2.E.
sp.p:
I've fixed the messenger. He's coming to the office tomorrow during one of his errands. I'm going to give him a Chile stamp for his collection.
[ Noise of laughing and horns ]
My! My! What a racket those waifs are making. Never get 'em still long enough to take 'em.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Going to take me, too, Alec?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: I'd rather take you than any girl in New York.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Think as much of me as you do of my chum, Kitty Ives?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
More.
[ Coming down to her ]
Say, Bess.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: What is it, Alec?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
I — er —
[ Aside ]
Strange! I can think of fifty ways to make a million or two, yet I can't find one way to tell her how much I love her.
[ Aloud ]
I'll tell you when I take your photograph.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: If you wait, it'll be too dark.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
This apparatus works best in the dark.
[ Business of pantomime ]
Flash! Make your own sunlight and there you are.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Coney Island picture.
[ Coming up ]

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
I don't warrant complexion, but I guarantee to get all your features in.
[ Picking up apparatus and starting, L. ]
Come along, Bess, you take the plates.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: My, but they're heavy!

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
They'll be heavier after I get the pictures of those stuffed kids on them.
[ Exeunt Bess and Alec, L.2.E., laughing. Enter Dick Van Buren, C.R., with overcoat, travelling satchel, etc., as though just having arrived from steamer. He is 32. The terrible mental strain is visible in his careworn face and whitening hair. Jasper follows with valise. He is followed by Creighton. a middle-aged man, of the regulation broker type ]

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.stage: Handing overcoat, hat, and wraps to Jasper
sp.p:
Take them to my room.
[ Exit Jasper, R.2.E. ]
You sent word to Paxton?

sp.speaker: Creigh.
sp.p: I telegraphed him, as soon as the ship was sighted off Fire Island.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Why didn't you cable me the minute there was a break in the United Western? Couldn't you see Cruger's hand in the move?

sp.speaker: Creigh.
sp.p: It was so well guarded!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
I saw it across the Atlantic. Why couldn't you see it across the street? Hang him!
[ Throwing small handbag on table, C. ]
I can't stir from
that office that Franklin Cruger doesn't take advantage of my absence. Creighton, your delay has cost us half a million.

sp.speaker: Creigh.
sp.p: Better let that go, Dick, than wreck McLean &.mp; Strong! The firm stood by us!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Let nothing go! Your tender heart would turn the Stock Exchange into a prayer meeting! There's a crisis staring us in the face, and friends and foes must go to keep us on our feet! If your conscience troubles you, stay at home and let me fight it out. I'll win, if I fill every almshouse from the Battery to King's Bridge!

sp.speaker: Creigh.
sp.p:
But, Dick — public opinion —
[ Enter Paxton, C.R., hurriedly down, R.C. ]

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Oh, success justifies everything! It's only failure that's called to account!

sp.speaker: Pax.
sp.p: Mr. Van Buren! You here!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: I'm still in Europe! You heard from me, by the Umbria today. I was in Vienna — sick — on my way to the south of Italy! Have me dead, if you want to! Cruger's died three times. All I want is to keep my presence in New York unknown for three days!

sp.speaker: Pax.
sp.p: Adams &.mp; Pell were buying up United Western last night, wherever they could get their hands on it.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: That's only a blind! How much are we carrying?

sp.speaker: Pax.
sp.p: Forty thousand shares — sixty days. If the rise continues — I'm afraid, sir —

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Cruger again!

sp.speaker: Creigh.
sp.p: Cruger?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Marsh, Fleming &.mp; Co., and Adams &.mp; Pell are both acting for him. Any day the market may be flooded, and we shall be swamped! Creighton, take a cab, and drive as quickly as you can to McLean &.mp; Strong. As fast as Marsh &.mp; Fleming sell, let them buy!

sp.speaker: Creigh.
sp.p: Adams &.mp; Pell are running up the price!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Part of Cruger's scheme! Bid against them. Keep the stock out of their hands at any cost! Buy — buy, till I tell you to stop. Go to my bedroom and see if the telephone is working to the office.

sp.speaker: Pax.
sp.p:
There's no one at the office today, sir.
[ Exit upstairs ]

sp.speaker: Creigh.
sp.p: I'll go to McLean's house. It is Christmas day.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
Hang these holidays! The week is short enough as it is!
[ Calls upstairs ]
Paxton, get your notebook ready.
[ To Creighton ]
Hurry, Creighton, and find McLean!
[ Exit Creighton, C. ]
The old fool! But I made my first step with his money. When I am through with him, I'll give him a pension. I'm shaking as though I had a chill! Not over the
voyage yet, I suppose.
[ Takes out flask of brandy from handbag, pours brandy in cup, as he continues ]
But, I'm back in time to set my foot on Cruger's neck! I'll work Chicago through Campbell &.mp; Son; St. Louis, through McVeigh &.mp; Co.
[ Drinks ]
Had the Umbria been twenty-four hours late, Cruger would have been master of the situation. He would have upset the scheme I've had in my head for months. Son-in-law to the man that holds this continent in his hand, my name will blanch the faces of every stock exchange in the world! — and then —
[ Pats flask in handbag ]
Yes, the only way to shake this king of Wall Street from his throne and take his place, is — to make Ann Cruger — my wife!
[ Goes up, C., hangs bag on hot-rack ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: Running on, L.2.E., looking around room ]
sp.p:
Oh, dear! Just as Alec was ready to take them — he missed his flash light! I wonder where it is.
[ Seeing Dick ]
Why, Dick!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Ah, little one!

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Where in the world did you come from?
[ Rushing into his arms ]

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
Bess, my darling!
[ Takes her in his arms and kisses her fondly ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
O Dick, Dick! Kiss me again!
[ Both come down, R. ]

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.stage: Sits on sofa, R.C., taking her on his lap
sp.p: Tell me, dear, how is mother?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Well — but worried about you. You're better now, aren't you, Dick?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Stronger than ever, little one.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Oh, I'm so glad! In your last letter from Paris, you promised me a great surprise.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: What was the last thing you said to me, before I left?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Oh! I said many things! Oh, I remember.
[ Rising, comes downstage a little ]
I told you that Kitty Ives was having a dress made at Worth's for the Charity Ball. And, if you had time, you might drop in and price one for me.
[ With sudden thought ]
Oh! you've bought it! I can see it in your face! How did you get the measure?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Eh? Why, I asked mother to get it from your dressmaker!

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: Throwing arms around his neck and kissing him
sp.p:
O Dick, you are so good!
[ Jumps up and walks as though she had train ]
A dress from Worth's!

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Where's that flash light?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Oh, I forgot; I'm coming.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: See here, little one. Bess, I don't want anyone to know of my return except John and mother.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: For reasons that you cannot understand.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Well, after a dress from Worth's, I'll tell everybody that you are in Jerusalem!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
Simply keep these little lips —
[ Kisses her ]
closed!

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: That locks them!

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Bess — s — s — s —

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Yes, Alec, I'm coming.
[ Goes up quickly, sees John, R.2.E. ]
Here's brother John! Get behind the curtains!
[ Excitedly, pushing him into alcove, L.C. ]
Get behind the curtains! Quick! When I say "Booh," come out!
[ Dick laughs and submits. Warningly, with uplifted finger ]
Mind now, don't stir until I say "Booh."
[ Enter John Van Buren, R.2.E. He is thirty-five years of age. No gray in his hair. Manner easy and natural. Dress that of fashionable clergyman of today. Bess impulsively ]
Brother John! Dick's behind that curtain!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: None of your tricks. Why, Dick's in Paris.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
No-o-o-o! Behind the curtain.
[ Gesticulating wildly towards curtains ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Dick.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Our Dick?
[ Crosses to curtains ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Yes. I put him there to surprise you. He wasn't to come out until I — oh — I forgot — Booh!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
Hello, John!
[ Comes down and grasps John's hand warmly. Bess starts upstage and gets flash light, comes down and with one arm around the neck of each, kisses John, then kisses Dick twice ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Why, Dick, Dick, old fellow, I'm so glad!

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: Darting under their clasped hands and going, L. Stops
sp.p: O Dick! May I tell angel you are here?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Oh, I'm so happy! A dress from Worth's.
[ Runs off with flash light, L.2.E. ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Dick, why didn't you cable us?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: I wanted to take Cruger unawares. I didn't dare trust a message, even to the wires.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: The doctor ordered absolute rest. You should have obeyed him.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: And let Cruger down me — but there, old fellow, aren't you glad to see me?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Glad? Why, ever since I saw your pale haggard face looking at me from the ship, as she moved out of the dock, I've looked forward to your return with an anxiety — well, that you ought to understand, knowing what we have been to each other.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: John, old fellow, you're a brick. But what was I to do? For months I have been maturing a plan —

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Always plans.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
This one, John, will place me at the top.
[ Music. His arm around John's neck ]
Old fellow, you're not practical enough.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: It is what I see in this practical world of yours that makes me fear for you.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
I'm all right.
[ Music; plaintive. Crosses to R., behind small table, R., during next speech ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Not long ago I stood by the bed of a dying man, whose name in the business world has been a synonym of honor. This money fever had seized him. More and more eager he became in his thirst for wealth, until he ended — a fugitive from home, body and soul burnt out by this delirium of speculation. As I listened to his words, a chill came over me. Dick, I was thinking of you.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.stage: Crosses to L. of small table, R. ]
sp.p: No, no! I love you all too much to let that be my end.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
He had loved ones, too.
[ During above, Dick has been nervously turning the leaves of album on small table, R. ]
Yet I never heard a sadder story than that of —

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.stage: Behind table, seeing picture in album, starting
sp.p: Phyllis Lee!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: You know her?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.stage: Crossing to R. of Dick, behind him ]
sp.p: You saw the name on the picture?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.stage: Crossing to Dick at table, R.
sp.p: Strange coincidence. It was of her father I was speaking.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: How came her picture in the album?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Because, Dick, the pity that I first felt for her became, after a time —

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
Does he love her?
[ Stop music ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.stage: Turns quickly, catches him in his arms ]
sp.p:
Dick! You see, you should not have returned so soon. You are in no fit condition for business.
[ Both cross to C. Enter Mrs. Van Buren, L.2.E. Aside, to Dick ]
Here's mother.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p:
My boy! my boy! I'm so glad you're home again.
[ Sinks her head on his breast ]

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
Mother, dear.
[ Arm around her ]
Remember, John, not a word of my presence here.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
His thoughts on Wall Street even in his mother's arms.
[ Sighs and turns up, exit R.U.E ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: It's at a time like this that I wish I were not blind. I want to see my boy! Come, come, tell me all about yourself.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
Presently, mother, presently! Tell me first about that picture in the album.
[ Crosses and sits on sofa ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p:
Picture?
[ Seated on sofa ]

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
A Miss Lee.
[ Music; plaintive ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Oh! John's protégée! Has he been speaking to you about her?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: He's very much interested in her. My! I forgot to let him know!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Has he heard from her recently?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p:
Why, you seem as much interested as John! I have invited her to come here to us for a while.
[ Phyllis comes slowly downstairs, R.3.E., crosses L. She does not see them ]

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
Coming here!
[ Aloud ]
When do you expect her?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p:
Why, she is —
[ Dick turns to L. Phyllis, who has come on, sees Dick and, with a start, stops. Dick sees her at same time, stands transfixed with surprise. She is about to speak his name and rush to him when he checks her. This mutual recognition, unknown to the blind mother, is marked. Dick goes to L. With pleasant smile, to Phyllis ]
If I am not mistaken, she is here now. Phyllis!

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Mrs. Van Buren!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p:
I want to introduce you to my boy.
[ To Phyllis ]
This is Phyllis Lee!
[ Goes R. in front of Dick. They do not bow or give any show of greeting to deceive the mother. As she is blind, the strength of the situation is in their remaining immovable ]
In the joy of my boy's unexpected return, I forgot to tell John of your arrival. I'll let him know. Dick, make Miss Lee realize that she is at home.
[ Exit, R.2.E. Music stops ]

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.stage: Rushes to him, clasps arms tightly around his neck
sp.p: Dick! Dick!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Be careful, Phyllis!

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: It's so long since I've seen you.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Yes, yes; I know, dear — but —

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Aren't you glad to see me?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Why, of course I am!

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p:
When father died and your brother said I must come here, I felt like going down on my knees and telling him of our
love. Nothing but my promise to you kept me silent. Dick, don't say I did wrong to come — don't!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
Why should I let a promise to a woman stand between me and success!
[ Goes R. ]

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: O Dick, don't let me live here a lie! They're all so good to me! Oh, when am I to take my place among them?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.stage: Off R. Dick back of table, R. Enter John, R.2.E.
sp.p:
Very well, mother, I'll send her to you.
[ Advancing, with outstretched hand ]
Welcome to the rectory!

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p:
Mr. Van Buren, you don't know how much those words mean to me.
[ Turns towards window ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Now that you have seen her, doesn't her sad face appeal to you?
[ Turns to Phyllis ]

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
If I could only tear this love out of my heart! I will!
[ Exit, R.2.E. ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: My mother wants you to go to the study. And, while you are talking to her, I'm going to consult Ann Cruger about you. She is the dearest friend I have in the world — and I want you to know her.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: You are so kind to me, Mr. Van Buren, that I —

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
It is my privilege.
[ Leading her R.2.E. ]
Come, mother is waiting for you. As the light of day never comes to her eyes, Heaven has put into her heart a sunlight, brightening the lives of all that look upon her face. Go to her. There must be no more sad days! In this house, you will find only happiness.
[ Exit Phyllis, R.2.E. ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.stage: Entering, L.U.E., takes off apron, places it and book in alcove
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Hello, Ann!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: I wondered if you had forgotten all about us!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: I was detained upon an urgent call. I'm so sorry not to have seen the children at their dinner.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: I have read Gulliver's Travels until I'm exhausted! They sent me to find out if you had come.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: I am sure they don't need anyone while they have you.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: 'Tis such a pleasure to me. I would have been alone today if I had stayed at home. Papa, of course, can't go to business, so he is spending the day with his brokers. They dine together.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Well, but don't you look upon this as your home?
[ Goes to her ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: It has always seemed so, John.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: You make us all as happy here, at Christmastide, as you have those children! It wouldn't seem like Christmas if you were not here to share it with us.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: And it wouldn't be Christmas to me if I had to spend it anywhere else!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.stage: Starting to go, L., with her
sp.p: Come, then! I don't want to deprive the children too long of their good fairy.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
Don't you try to bolt from me, sir! Hold on to him, Jasper! Hold on to him! Where are the police? Somebody! Anybody!
[ Enters, R.2.E. He is about 55, hale, vigorous, quaint in attire, old-fashioned in his methods. To Ann ]
Ann, I am glad to find you!
[ Coming down, puts his hat on stand, R., and throws overcoat on back of sofa. To John ]
Hello, John! "Tantaene animis coelestibus irae"?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Why are you storming away in Latin?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: It's safer, in a clergyman's presence. Besides, my English would disgrace me! In my judicial capacity, I have sentenced everything from a bootblack to a blackmailer, from a wife-beater to a lady-killer! But never has there appeared before me such a corpuscle of humanity as I have just deposited in the hall!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Goodness!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: I came upon him as he was breaking into the parish buildings.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Through one of the windows?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: No, squeezing himself through one of the gratings!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: How could he do it?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Do it? He looked as if he could eat an iron bar!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Heavens!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
Come in, you flotsam, jetsam, ligan — "Flotsam": goods found floating at sea; "Jetsam": goods cast overboard, but sunk; "Ligan": goods cast overboard, with buoy attached. What, you won't?
[ Starting out, R. ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Shall I help you, judge?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
No. Alone, I captured him; single-handed I'll bring him here.
[ Goes off, R.2.E. ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.stage: Crosses L., down. Going extreme L. ]
sp.p: Well, I'm afraid to stay.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
Let him go, Jasper! The strong right hand of the law is upon him.
[ Judge reappears, dragging on Cain, a mite of a boy, ragged, coatless, shoeless, his shirt peeping through a rent in his trousers, his face pale and pinched. Holds him at arm's length ]
There! What do you say to that?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: That you were right — you dear old god-father — to bring him here.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
And I thought it was some desperate criminal.
[ Comes C. ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
Criminal? Isn't that criminal enough? Criminal negligence! We send missionaries to "Borioboolagha," with a thing like that on our doorstep! Come here!
[ Puts boy on chair ]
Get up here and let's have a look at you.
[ Boy turns back to audience, showing rent ]
Turn around the other way, sir!
[ Turns, facing audience ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
Poor little fellow!
[ Takes both his hands ]
Why, how cold your hands arc!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: And he looks hungry.

sp.speaker: Ann
sp.p:
Hungry!
[ Calls, L. ]
Sophie!
[ L. of Cain ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Ann, have you got a pin?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Yes, here! What do you want it for?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
Your sex is altogether too inquisitive.
[ Sophie appears, L.2.E. ]
You tell Sophie what you want with her.
[ Ann goes up, gives directions. Judge meanwhile quickly stuffs shirt in trousers, and pins up rent ]
There! I have expelled the winter's flaw. Now then, sit down!
[ Cain sits, springs up with cry of pain ]

sp.speaker: Judge and Ann .
sp.p:
What's the matter?
[ Exit Sophie, L.2.E. ]

sp.speaker: Cain .
sp.p: Pin!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: O judge!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Ann, if you had given me a safety pin, that wouldn't have happened.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
Why, what is this!
[ Takes cigarettes from boy's pocket ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Cigarettes!

sp.speaker: Cain .
sp.p:
Gi' me um!
[ Snatches them from her, puts one in his mouth ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
Can I get you a light? They would kill a goat! Avenue A. Perfectos!
[ Throws them on floor, R. ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: What's your name?

sp.speaker: Cain .
sp.p: Cain!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Eh?

sp.speaker: Cain .
sp.p: Cain!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Cain! Cain what?

sp.speaker: Cain .
sp.p: Cain nothin'. Just plain Cain!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Where did you get that name?

sp.speaker: Cain .
sp.p: A kind lady called me that because she said I was a wanderer on the face of the earth!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: What is your father's name?

sp.speaker: Cain .
sp.p: Burglin' Billy!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Ann, you ask him his mother's name. I'm afraid.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: But your mother, little boy. She has a name?

sp.speaker: Cain .
sp.p: Never had no mother!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Oh! Poor little — um. Where's your father?

sp.speaker: Cain .
sp.p: In jail!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
Have you any brothers or sisters?
[ Cain nods head ]
Where are they?

sp.speaker: Cain .
sp.p: In jail!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Where do you expect to go?

sp.speaker: Cain .
sp.p: Jail!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
John, the law gives him up!
[ Hands Cain to John ]
I hand him over to the Church!
[ Goes R. ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: And the Church hands him over to the care of Woman. Here, Ann, you take him!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
Yes, Ann can raise Cain if she likes!
[ Aside ]
I never saw a woman who couldn't!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
I told Sophie to get some turkey, pudding, ice cream, oranges —
[ Watching effect of each word ]

sp.speaker: Cain .
sp.stage: Grin on face, as he rubs his stomach ]
sp.p: Yum! Gee whiz!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: I have sent for enough to make even a strong man tremble!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Why, a strong man is nothing to a small boy like that.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
But first I must take you upstairs and wash your face!
[ Showing his face ]
Look at that! Come along, little boy!
[ Exit with Cain upstairs, R.3.E. ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
Well, if Ann puts Cain in the bathtub, there'll be nothing left of him!
[ Aside ]
Mrs. De Peyster is here; Jasper told me so. I gave him a dollar. It was worth it.
[ Aloud ]
John, I was afraid I wouldn't be in time to see Ann, with the children. A coal cart broke down in front of my car and blockaded the whole road!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Why didn't you take the elevated?
[ Goes down, R. ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: No, I never do that, on principle. We hurry enough through life nowadays without rushing upstairs to ride in the air! I tried it once. John, when we went around that 110th Street curve, I could have sworn I heard harps. There is only one way one travels with a dignified and stately ease. That's the Belt Line. That takes me back forty years to the time when your father and I used to run with the machine, along with Harry Howard, Zophar Mills and the rest of the boys. Ah, John, times have changed — times have changed! Why, it was only yesterday, in court, young Livingston — a fledgling, just beginning to toddle, with the aid of Blackstone under one arm and Chitty On Pleading under the other — had the impertinence to teach me law! When I told him that I had sat on the bench for thirty years, what do you think he replied?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Why, what?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
"Get up, and give the bench a rest."
[ John laughs heartily ]
I gave him a night's rest in jail for contempt of court!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Never mind, judge! There is one person who believes in you thoroughly.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Oh! Your dear mother?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: No, I — I alluded to Mrs. De Peyster.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Charming woman! Delightful woman! I called upon her today, to pay my respects, but she was out.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: She is here!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: You don't tell me!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Oh, yes, yes.
[ Aside ]
As if he didn't know.
[ Aloud ]
I was just on my way to see the children in the parish buildings, where she is now.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: John, I don't mind telling you. Do you know, she came very near being Mrs. Peter Gurney Knox?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Indeed! What prevented?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
Oh, nothing! Only, De Peyster was too quick for me! However, he was one of your fast livers, and got through early. Now, John —
[ Takes his arm, confidentially ]
you are my clergyman, and it's no more than right that you should know the state of my feelings towards one of your clients —
[ Correcting himself ]
I mean, parishioners.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: You don't mean to tell me that you love her still!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: That's it, John, — a still love. I'm getting along in years — face a little furrowed. But, John, there are no wrinkles on my heart. Ha, ha, ha! I saw her last night at the theatre; and she looked so radiant that I was determined to bring this matter to an issue at once; and I want to borrow this room to do it in!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: With pleasure! I'll send her to you!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: If you will be so kind!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Certainly, certainly!
[ Sees Mrs. De Peyster ]
Fortune favors the brave! She is coming this way!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Well, John, on second thought, I'll just step aside, and then come in and take her accidentally, you know.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Oh, you'll come in accidentally!
[ Judge exit, R.2.E.; forgets hat and overcoat ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Mr. Van Buren, may I trouble you for your arm? I'm afraid I've sprained my ankle!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: I trust not!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Dear! I can hardly stand!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Sit here!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
Oh, I thought the coast was clear. I'm not ready for a clergyman yet!
[ Exit hurriedly ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Will you kindly ask Alec to come to me?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Certainly — certainly!
[ Goes L.2.E., looks off R. ]
She is now at his mercy!
[ Exit, L.2.E. ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p:
Dear, dear! I do hope this will pass off before Judge Knox arrives! There is no misunderstanding that letter! "When next we meet, prepare to be astounded." Yes, he means to propose!
[ Sees Judge's hat, crosses to it ]
Eh? Why, that looks like his hat! It is — "Knox." Dear, dear, but he must be here! I should be mortified to be obliged to limp during a declaration of love!
[ Starts to go, R. ]
Before he comes, I'll apply some arnica.
[ Judge enters, as before, comes down, C. ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Ah, my esteemed friend!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p:
Too late!
[ Stands with difficulty, trying to conceal from Judge that she is in pain ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: This is indeed an unexpected delight!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: How do you do, judge; how do you do?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Our first meeting since your return! I should have arrived sooner if I had known you were here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Oh, come, come, judge! You haven't just arrived.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Oh, but —

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Isn't this your hat?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
Where did I get that hat? I suppose I shall find my brains in the lining!
[ Aloud ]
Well, to tell the truth, I was here, and when I heard you coming —

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: You ran away!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
The evidence of this witness — is so conclusive — that any attempt at prevarication would only render myself liable —
[ Bowing ]
to the contempt of the court.

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: I feel my ankle swelling.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: I never saw you looking better!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Thank you, judge!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
The bloom of the peach is on your cheek, the sparkle of the diamond in your eye! The air of contented ease with which you stand there —
[ Mrs. De Peyster looks up, showing pain ]
is only equalled, when you walk, by that poetry of motion that always charms me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p:
Thanks, judge!
[ Aside ]
I would rather die than move an inch!
[ Aloud ]
O judge, you spoil me!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Did you receive a letter from me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: A letter? Oh, yes!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.stage: Turns up, R., to get chair
sp.p: I will now explain why I wrote it!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p:
He is going to — to —
[ Sits quickly ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: You remarked?

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p:
Nothing, judge; nothing.
[ Aside ]
Oh, dear! To be so afflicted at such a moment!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.stage: Bringing down chair, sitting L. of Mrs. De Peyster
sp.p: I wish to warn you against a certain man whose name I will not mention. He has designs upon you!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: On me, judge?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Don't be alarmed. As your legal adviser, I shall protect you. Unfortunately, I am his legal adviser also, and must look after his interests. He loves you — loved you long before your De Peyster experience.

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Ah, judge!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: But he has none of those soft ways that ladies admire.

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: And yet you plead his cause?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: As his legal adviser.

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: This shoe is killing me!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: He is a bad-tempered, selfish, inconsiderate man — a man well calculated to render any woman's life unendurable. From infancy, I have been his most intimate friend! And I warn you against him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: And his name, judge?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Peter Gurney Knox!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: O judge, you give yourself such a character!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: As your legal adviser!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: It is for you to give the decision. I have summed up for both clients. I leave the matter in the hands of the court!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p:
I cannot endure this another moment!
[ Moves to R. of sofa ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
You hesitate —
[ Comes down to L. of sofa ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: O judge —

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: I warn you — if you decide against my client, Knox — we will appeal the case.

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: O judge, I am suffering such intense pain!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.stage: Sitting by her side, on sofa
sp.p: On my account?

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Oh, no, no! I would have told you before, but I thought I could conceal it. I didn't wish to distress you. But this pain is —

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: In your heart?

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: No. In my foot. An accident!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: An accident?

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: But oblige me by dismissing it from your mind!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Then, may I hope? Speak, Camilla.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Want me, auntie?

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Thank heaven!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: To interrupt proceedings, at such a juncture —

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Judge, you were all wrong about that Livingston affair.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: I hope, sir, I taught him proper decorum in the presence of the court!

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: You broke up our party at the Casino. 'Twas Bob's night to put up the supper, too. The idea of committing a fellow for a little thing like that.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
The next time he has a case before me, he'll give the bench a rest.
[ Goes to piano, up R. ]

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: I'll get square with the judge yet!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p:
Alec! Alec! Open the door! Open the door! I've sprained my ankle. I don't want the judge to see me leave the room.
[ She goes L., limping. Alec opens folding doors. Before reaching them, with a cry of pain, she sinks into large armchair. Alec wheels it out of room and closes doors quickly, standing before them facing Judge, who turns in time to see her disappear. They look at each other for a moment ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Most remarkable manner of leaving a room!

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: A little hurried!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Nothing serious, I hope? She spoke of her foot.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Yes; her foot is off!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Her foot is off —

sp.speaker: Aec .
sp.p:
I wonder if he knows she has a sprained ankle?
[ Aloud ]
Of course, judge, you know what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: She spoke of an accident.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: She didn't tell you what it was?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Oh, no! Of course not! She couldn't!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
Oh! This is too good! I can't lose it!
[ Aloud ]
I say, judge, today's the first time you've seen auntie since she returned from Paris?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
Did you notice a slight impediment in her gait? Sort of a kind of —
[ Pantomime ]
That sort of thing?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Now you mention it, she didn't move.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Yes! Auntie is terrible sensitive about it.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: About what, sir; about what?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: I can't confide this thing, except under certain circumstances. Now, judge, man to man, is there anything between you and auntie?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Why, yes. I have this day invited your esteemed auntie to become Mrs. Knox!

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Then you ought to know! The accident she referred to happened in Paris, and the result of it was —

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Was what, sir; was what?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
Well —
[ Whispers in his ear ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.stage: Aghast. Sinks in chair, R. of table, C. ]
sp.p:
C-o-r-k!
[ Work lights down gradually, very slowly ]

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
On the "Q.T.," judge!
[ Draws hand quickly across leg, just above ankle ]
To there!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: To where?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.stage: Draws hand across leg, just below knee ]
sp.p: To there!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.stage: Groan of despair, buries head in hands on table
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
I say, judge, auntie's a good business investment. When she becomes Mrs. Knox — if you ever got into trouble — she'll keep you afloat!
[ Exit, L.2.E. ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
I must withdraw! It must be done honorably, but I must withdraw. That cork member stands between us! And I am invited to meet her at dinner this evening.
[ Takes coat and hat ]
I will ask Mrs. Van Buren to place me as far as possible from her. If they serve me with the second joint of the turkey and she looks at me, I shall betray myself at once! Love! Sweet misery! Only to think of it! Some of her here and some of her gone to join De Peyster!
[ Exit, R.2.E. Enter Bess, L.2.E. Warn music ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: Goes up and gets matches from mantel ]
sp.p:
Come along, Mr. Betts!
[ Enter Phyllis, R.2.E. ]

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p:
In his home! My home by right! And Dick was so cold — so strange — to me! Not even glad to see me. Oh, if I have no place here, what will become of me?
[ Betts enters with lamp, places it on table, C. ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Thank you!
[ Seeing Phyllis. Ring music ]
Why, you've come downstairs! You never could guess what this is for! When brother John is at home, he puts his lamp in the study window. Then, if anyone in trouble wants to see him, all that person has to do is to turn the knob of the little door that opens on the street, next to the chapel, and walk in.

sp.speaker: Betts .
sp.p: It's a way Mr. Van Buren has of making things easy for those that need him.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Let me light the lamp tonight!

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Why, of course! It will celebrate your coming here.
[ Hands it to Phyllis, who lights lamp ]
Will you put the lamp in the window, Mr. Betts?
[ Stop music ]

sp.speaker: Betts .
sp.p:
Why, of course I will —
[ Takes up lamp and sings as he exits, R.2.E. ]
"There's a light in the window for thee."

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
I want to introduce Alec to you, Miss Lee. I've told him all about you. He's just dying to take your photograph!
[ Exeunt Bess and Phyllis, L.U.E.; firelight in alcove floods room. As scene progresses, the sunset fades away into twilight. Ann Cruger comes downstairs, R.3.E., with Cain. His face is washed, and hair combed. Has piece of pie in his hand, of which he occasionally takes a bite ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Well, come along, little fellow! Did you have enough to eat?

sp.speaker: Cain .
sp.p: I've eaten so much, mum, I'm tired!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
You hate to waste that pie, don't you?
[ Jasper goes on, L.2.E., lights the three electric lamps in alcove, up C., lights piano lamp, then electric lamp above platform, R.3.E., and exit, R.2.E. ]

sp.speaker: Cain .
sp.p: I'm loadin' up now for tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: You must take care of today! I'll take care of tomorrow!

sp.speaker: Cain .
sp.p: You're awful good to a little son-of-a-gun!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
Poor little fellow! Why, you are so sleepy you can hardly keep your eyes open!
[ Takes him to rocking chair, in alcove, and arranges him ]
You just come here, little fellow; I'll fix you up comfortable. Come here, dear! There! Isn't that comfortable?
[ Cain is almost asleep ]
Did you say it was comfortable?
[ Aside ]
Poor little fellow. Why, I believe he's asleep already! And to think that he's only one of thousands in this great city!
[ Sophie enters, L.2.E., with armful of toys ]
Sh! Sophie, will you bring me a cup of tea?
[ Ann takes toys from Sophie who exits, R.2.E. Ann then fills Cain's lap with toys, humming softly Sullivan's "Lullaby," then pauses ]
Oh, I can't keep Bess's words out of my mind. "I've heard brother John tell angel that he didn't know what he would do without you — that he had in his heart such a feeling for you — "
[ Continues "Lullaby" and arranges toys ]
Oh, how my heart beats! Alone, I may speak the words: "John, I love you." There! Now then, when he wakes up, he'll think —

sp.speaker: John .
sp.stage: Entering L.2.E. Going to Cain, placing hand lightly upon his head
sp.p:
That an angel has been here!
[ Music ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
Sh!
[ Down R.C. ]

sp.speaker: Cain .
sp.p: Awful — good — to a little son-of-a-gun —

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Alec is taking their pictures — individually — and in groups — on their feet — on their heads!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Yes, I know! They are having a glorious time!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: And it's all owing to you! Ann, there is something I want to say to you. I must tell you tonight. Now — while we are alone.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Is it so very important?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: My happiness depends upon it!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
My heart will betray me!
[ Enter Sophie, R.2.E., carrying salver, with small teapot, sugar dish, 2 cups and saucers, a plate of biscuits. Places it on table. takes box of matches, which Bess has left on table, exits, L.2.E. ]
I said I wanted a cup of tea, but I don't! Thank you, Sophie.
[ Nervously ]
John, won't you have a sip of cake and a bite of tea — no, no — I mean — a bite of tea and a sip of cake — Well, here are cake and tea!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Why, Ann, you seem confused!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.stage: Crosses in front to L. of table ]
sp.p: Well, no — I can't see to talk very well in the twilight.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: I'll turn up the light.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Oh, no! No — not on my account! Won't you have a cup of tea?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.stage: Drawing chair from R. up to table, C. ]
sp.p: Thank you — no. While you take yours, I'll speak to you.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Well, I hope I won't disturb you. I'm as hungry as a bear!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.stage: Sitting at table so as not to face her, unconscious of her embarrassment
sp.p:
Ann, you and I have been near to each other all our lives.
[ Business. Ann putting several lumps of sugar in cup ]
As children, we were playmates, read together out of the same books — and now that we are man and woman, it seems natural for me to share all my confidences. You have been such a help to me in my work! I don't know what I could do without you! You have made everybody happy here today. The heart that has room for so many must have room for one more.
[ Looking at her ]
But you are not eating, and you said you were hungry!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Oh, yes, yes! I am! Go on, John! I am listening.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: I love someone, whose heart I do not know. The dread of interfering with the friendship that now exists between us has kept me silent.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Have you ever shown her that you care for her?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: She may have guessed it.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Her discernment must be better than mine, for this is the first time I ever suspected that you were in love.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: What am I to do?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Much depends upon the woman. I suppose you're aware — you haven't told me who she is.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: She is an angel!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.stage: Cup raised to her lips, without drinking
sp.p: Is she a New York angel?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: I met her first in Florida.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.stage: Slowly lowering the cup from her lips, without drinking
sp.p: Florida!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: I was sent for, to minister to the last hours of her father. I looked across the bed of sickness. I saw her kneeling on the other side. She turned her eyes to me. I saw in them a look that told of suffering — a mute appeal that made me pity her. And as I looked, I loved.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.stage: Half dazed, but with a superhuman effort to control herself
sp.p:
Loved!
[ At this moment chimes are heard for evening service. They continue till end of act ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Something in her face as it looked into mine connected her with my life.
[ Rises ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: You are speaking of Phyllis Lee?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Now do you understand why I ask you to find room in your heart for one more?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.stage: L., slowly raising her eyes to him ]
sp.p: Yes, John.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
I must go now to be ready for evening service. When you know her, tell me what to do.
[ Exit, R.2.E. ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
He — loves — Phyllis — Lee. Phyllis Lee —
[ Cain, who is asleep in alcove, makes a movement which causes the toys to fall to the floor. Ann's attention is attracted to him ]
Ah, little fellow, I thought you were very wretched, but there are lots of people in this world who have plenty to eat and plenty to wear —
[ Rising ]
and yet are a thousand times more wretched than you — more wretched than you.
[ Ann throws herself on steps leading up into alcove at Cain's feet, sobbing aloud. Cain wakes up and regards her wonderingly as curtain falls ]

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: Scene : Anteroom of corridor at the Metropolitan Opera House, New York, brilliantly lighted, and decorated with rare plants. Through windows is seen the snow, covering exterior. A bleak winter's night. No snow falling. Light effects seen through windows. The night of the Charity Ball two weeks later. Waltz heard off ballroom, L.

Discovered : Jasper, entering R.U.E. with silver water pitcher, two silver goblets, and a napkin on small salver. He crosses and is about to exit, when Alec enters, L.U.E., running against him, upsetting the supposed water on the threshold .

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
I beg your pardon!
[ Coming R. ]
That's what I've been doing all night — upsetting things! I'm upset myself.
[ Crossing to Jasper, L., and handing him coin ]
Here! Remove the flood,
[ Jasper picks up pitcher and goblets, sops up supposed water with napkin and exit, L.1.E. ]
When I started Judge Knox on that cork joke, I never thought it would turn out so serious. Oh, I'm in an awful fix!
[ Looking at card ]
Next dance — polka — Bess. Next quadrille — Bess. Next schottische — Bess. I've got all the shares in that girl, anyhow! No margin for any other fellow tonight.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Alec, what did you run away for?
[ At arch, C., about to come in room ]

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: I didn't want to meet Judge Knox. Be careful, Bess!

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: You're in a pool!

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Oh, gracious!

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
And you've slippers on, with paper soles! I can't do as Sir Walter Raleigh did with his Queen Bess — nineteenth century etiquette will not permit! However, I can modernize their version of it.
[ Takes out large silk handkerchief, and in a knightly manner spreads it out for her to walk over, kneeling, and extending his L. hand to her ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
O Sir Alec, how thoughtful of you!
[ With comically royal manner, she is about to cross on tiptoe ]

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.stage: She passes over handkerchief à la Raleigh and Elizabeth, and goes well down, R. He takes up handkerchief and presses it to his heart
sp.p: It shall never he washed again!

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Where were you all the afternoon?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Detained at the Hoffman House.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Why do you go there so much?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: A fellow wouldn't be in the swim at all, if he didn't stop at the Hoffman on his way uptown.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Is the food better there than anywhere else?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: You'd think so to see the fellows sitting around the tables striking matches. Besides, you get a whole art gallery thrown in.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Like the Eden Musée?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Yes, only the figures are moving.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: What do they do?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Principally raise their hands to their mouths. And Bess, while you take your little fizz and look at the pictures —

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Fizz?
[ Stop music ]

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: I mean as you look at the pictures, your phiz is turned that way.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Slang!

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: We fellows all use it downtown. Have to — they wouldn't understand you if you spoke English below Canal Street.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Is the art gallery very beautiful?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: One picture there worth ten thousand dollars.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: What is the subject?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
Oh — er — a beach scene — lot of folks going in bathing — just like Long Branch or Narragansett Pier at the height of the season. You — I — can't exactly explain it to ladies — when ladies are there, you stand very silent, you look at it, and then you all pass on, as if you hadn't seen it.
[ Crossing to R. ]
Now, Bess, when you are my wife —

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: I haven't said I would be yet!

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Well, say, will you?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Oh, I must have time to think!

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: You are too young to think. Nobody ever thinks now, when they get married! Come, say "Yes" and be done with it!

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Well, yes. How long will we have to wait?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Oh, till I make a million or two!

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Can't we be married until then?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Not in New York.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Well, brother John, in his sermons, says we ought to deny ourselves. I could live in Brooklyn.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
And I cross the river twice a day!
[ Crosses, L., to Bess ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: We'd be as happy as Hero and Leander. I'd be Hero and you Leander.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
Excuse me, Bess!
[ Alec goes R., Bess L. Enter Dick, R.U.E., and comes down. C. ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: L. of Dick; Alec, R. of Dick
sp.p: O Dick!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Ah, little one.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: How do you like it?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
Oh, exquisite!
[ Holds her hands and regards her affectionately ]
But it doesn't compare with the loveliness of my little sister!
[ Bess goes up, L., looks off ]

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
Mr. Van Buren, that was a terrible shaking up you gave the old man today. Oh, we don't call you the "Earthquake" for nothing! When
I saw Mr. Cruger hanging over the ticker in the office, and making the air blue, in an undertone, I unloaded my two shares of Great Western preferred to auntie.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Had you been carrying half a million, I suppose it would have made no difference?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Only, instead of auntie supporting me, I should now be supporting auntie.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Wouldn't that be good of him?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
Worthy of Alexander the Great!
[ Music ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Come, Alec, that's our dance. Judge Knox is looking for a couple to fill the set.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: He can't get me! We'll go round by way of the box and get as far away from him as possible.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Why are you afraid of Judge Knox?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
O Bess, I'm in an awful fix!
[ Exeunt Bess and Alec, R.2.E. ]

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
Ah, little Bess, you are the one thing on this earth that makes me, now and then, forget business! If you could as easily make me forget Phyllis Lee! Ah, I have enough on my mind without that! I came here for work. Had the exchange been open but an hour longer today — But I made Cruger feel my power! — and tonight, he's in a condition to listen to me!
[ Enter Cruger, L.U.E. ]

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Ah, Van Buren, just on my way to the smoking room to have a cigar. By the way, pleasant little shock that was you gave us today!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: A few more like it will shake some of the names off the office doors, downtown!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p:
Very cleverly done!
[ Crosses to R., in front of Dick. Dick crosses, L. ]
Join me in a smoke? You might give me a few points!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: I will — tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Van Buren, I like your grit! The fight went your way today because I held my reserves. But, now that you have combined with Campbell in Chicago, and McVeigh in St. Louis, to push me to the wall, I mean to sweep you into oblivion!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: It can't be done, Mr. Cruger; it can't be done, sir! Until I came into the street, you feared no man. All feared you. Now you, with the rest, fear me! One firm after another has gone to pieces under my touch. You are the only man that blocks my way. And do you think I'll stop? I have no religion, no God, but one ambition — to be master of the street!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: My sole aim in life is money. Show me how I can make more than I do now, and I'll abdicate in your favor.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: My only regret is that I must fight against the father of Ann Cruger.

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Why, what has that to do with it?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: I love her.

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Love Ann?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Well, well, well! Does Ann know it?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: I can't ask a woman to be my wife when I'm trying to ruin her father!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Why not? It's business! Besides, it would tie your hands and give me a little rest. But Ann may not love you.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: She may not be indifferent when she sees the advantage that must come to us all.

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p:
You never lose a trick, do you? Well, I'll do all I can to help you, Dick; for, as my son-in-law, I look upon you as a devilish good investment.
[ Crosses, L., in front of Dick ]

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
Once his partner, I shall stand alone!
[ Dick retires up L.C., takes glass of water from water-cooler and off, R.U.E. ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Mr. Cruger!
[ Enter Bess, excitedly, R.2.E. R.C. ]
O Mr. Cruger, come to Alec!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: What's the trouble?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: We were dancing, way on the further side of the ballroom, when Judge Knox spied him. He was coming towards us and Alec ran and hid in Box L.

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: What's he been doing to the judge?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Oh, he's in an awful fix!
[ Exit Bess, R.2.E., greatly disturbed, holding Cruger's hand. Cruger, laughing, exits with her. Enter Judge Knox, L.2.E., wearing badge of Reception Committee on right breast ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
Two more weeks like the past, and I shall become a howling maniac!
[ Badge comes off and drops on floor. He stoops, picks it up ]
Confound that badge! If I hadn't been on the committee of the Charity Ball for the past twenty years, I shouldn't be here tonight!
[ Looking off, into ballroom, L.2. ]
The most remarkable thing about it is that she moves with perfect ease. I must interrogate Alexander further on the subject. I wonder where he disappeared to? Christmas day I managed to struggle through the dinner — I don't know what I ate. I was trying to avoid looking at Mrs. De Peyster. Every time she moved, I imagined I could hear it squeak! Dinner over, I made my excuses. The next morning I was on the Limited Express, bound for Chicago. Two days afterwards, she accepted me, by letter. She has
made our engagement public, and tonight I have been congratulated by dozens of people. Here's a dilemma! Linked for life to a fraction of a woman! After two weeks of investigation, I find that even Chicago cannot grapple with a case like this!
[ Badge falls ]
Hang that badge!
[ Picks it up and puts it in R. vest pocket. Turns up, L., looking into ballroom, L. ]

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p:
Brainy old Knox to be hoaxed like that! When Alec told me, I thought I should expire! There he is! I'll put him out of his misery!
[ To Judge Knox; Cruger, R. ]
Ah, judge —

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Ah, how are you, Cruger? How are you?

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Oh, nothing, nothing!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: You seem troubled.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Oh, no, no; I'm gleesome, I'm airy.

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Oh, no. That won't do! I've know you too long for you to try to deceive me. There's something on your mind.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Yes. Cork!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Cork, Knox?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Did I say "cork?" I'm getting light-headed!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p:
How the deuce shall I broach the subject?
[ Aloud ]
From your allusion, Knox, I infer that you have become attorney for some — er — cork trust.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: What do you mean by that? What do you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Why, judge —

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: I consider that personal, sir!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: I simply want to tell you something, in reference to your engagement.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: I don't want to hear it!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: But you ought to know!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: I don't want to know! I know too much already. You're always chaffing me! I won't have it, sir!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Now mind, while I don't approve of what has been done —

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Approve? What the devil has that got to do with it? You don't think I am going to ask your consent to my marriage, do you?

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: When you hear me out, you will agree with me that the joke is —

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Joke! How dare you allude to it as a joke! It's no joke! I'm in misery!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Misery?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Oh, I must be careful or I shall betray my bride.

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Now listen to me and have a good laugh.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I shall never laugh again!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: But I insist!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Oh, yes. That's like you stock brokers! You expect a man to laugh at your funny stories with pandemonium staring him in the face! Oh, I know. I had a Wall Street experience once!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Perhaps you were not in the right company.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Oh, yes, I was!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: What were you? A bear?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: A bull?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Oh! A lamb?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Well, what were you, then?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
An ass!
[ Cruger laughs heartily. Judge turns toward Cruger ]
Thank heaven you're all going to the same place! And, Cruger, you'll get a red-hot corner!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Do you think there'll be any left when you lawyers have been provided for?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Oh, we lawyers can take care of ourselves.

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Yes, you're better known there.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: But we're being fast crowded out by the monopolists.

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p:
Only let me make a corner, and when you and I meet, you'll find me smiling.
[ Crosses, L. ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
I generally do. I suppose you old boys of the street will get together and form an ice-cream and linen-duster trust.
[ They cross around each other ]

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: You don't mean to say that we stockbrokers are all bound that way?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: No. But your chances are darned good!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p:
Well, I'll be hanged if I tell him at all now. I'm sorry for Alec, but, if I'm to roast, I'll keep Knox in a stew!
[ Aloud ]
Well, I give it up. I give it up. All jokes aside, I congratulate you upon your engagement. Confidentially now, when Mrs. De Peyster returned from Paris this time, I knew she would take steps to win you.
[ Judge winces ]
Ha, ha, ha! I'd have given a good deal to have seen you throw yourself at her feet!
[ Judge winces ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Feet! What are rights and lefts to her?

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Ah, here she comes!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
Eh?
[ Enter Mrs. De Peyster, L.2.E. ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Ah! Mr. Cruger, and Judge Knox, too!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Now, to look at her, who would imagine that she has a drawback!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p:
I'm glad you came out here. The judge is a little downcast today. I've been trying to buoy him up.
[ Judge winces ]
Ha, ha, ha! No doubt you will succeed better. Ha, ha, ha!
[ Exit, L.2.E., chuckling. Mrs. De Peyster looks L. as he exits ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: I hope Dick Van Buren will get that man in a corner tomorrow and pound the life out of him!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Judge, it is two weeks since I've seen you and, with the exception of a hasty "How do you do" tonight, you haven't spoken a word to me!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
Well, you see, my duties on the committee are such that I am kept constantly on the hop, skip and jump, as it were.
[ Aside, as she comes forward ]
She doesn't even limp!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: One would imagine that you had forgotten Christmas afternoon!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Oh, no, I shall never forget it!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: If you hadn't been called away so abruptly after dinner, I would have relieved your anxiety.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Well, I felt that I must go to Chicago.

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Oh, the look you gave me as you rushed from the room! Messonier would have taken you as a model for mad Leah in the storm. I never realized until that night what a head you had.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: She ought to have seen it the next morning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.stage: Going L.; Judge watching her walk ]
sp.p: I awoke early. My broker rang me up. I connect with him by telephone, you know. But I shut him off. Quotations had no charm for me that day. I confided what you had said to me to Polly.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Polly?

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Yes, my parrot; Mr. De Peyster's first present to me.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: She understood every word I said!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: And what do you think she did?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: I don't know. What?

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
