sp.p: Nodded her head and winked her eye! A trick Mr. De Peyster had taught her whenever he wanted me to say "Yes" to anything.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Then you accepted me on the recommendation of that parrot?

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: I'd like to twist Polly's neck!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p:
But I'm so glad you're back! I wanted some advice. Ever since Dick Van Buren's return, United Western has been falling and rising in a manner to bewilder one. I was carrying a block. After selling at 921¼, stock jumped four points. A terrible slump, and —
[ Goes R. ]
if I hadn't dipped in oil, I shouldn't have glided out with so good a balance.
[ Walks to and fro. During this speech, Mrs. De Peyster walks back and forth, the Judge, meanwhile, trying to see her feet ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
I have it! I will object to her stock jobbing! Perhaps she'll discard me!
[ Aloud ]
If there is one thing that I strenuously oppose, it is a woman in stocks!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Oh, I couldn't exist if I didn't dabble in stocks — just a little.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: No, no. I could never permit it!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Peter!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
No, no, no! I stand upon that, with both feet!
[ Checks himself suddenly and turns upstage, L. ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p:
Oh, but I will! And when I put my foot down —
[ Stamps ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: She alludes to it!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Why should you object?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Well, imagine my feelings, some evening, in passing through the lobby of the Waldorf, to hear one of those stockbrokers confiding to a brother bear that he had Mrs. Knox in a corner that day and squeezed her!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p:
Only a figure of speech!
[ Warn music ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Oh, I object to having my wife hugged, in any manner, by a member of the Stock Exchange!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: You are unnecessarily severe!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Oh, I know them! I know them!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: This is delicious!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Delicious? It is outrageous! You must give up stocks, madam, or give me up!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: I would give up everything in the world, Peter, sooner than give you up!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
That settles it!
[ Aside ]
We are doomed to be a matrimonial tripod!
[ Music ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Why, where are you wearing your badge?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: I don't know! I don't know!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.stage: Taking badge from the Judge's pocket and pinning it on his coat
sp.p:
Oh, listen to that music! Isn't it enchanting?
[ Sways in time to the music ]
You haven't asked me to dance yet, Peter!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Do you dance?

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Why — do I dance? What a question!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: How do you manage it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Manage? Manage what?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Well, with only one — er — er — that is — when — er — you haven't got — er — both — that is, with only one good one, you know?

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p:
What is the matter with you, Peter? Oh, listen to the waltz! Oh, listen to the waltz! Isn't it charming?
[ With slight movement in time with music ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Great heaven! She has wound it up!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p:
Peter, you shall dance this with me!
[ Taking hold of him ]
Come, let us join the others, in the ballroom!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
I wonder which side it's on. I want to keep out of its way.
[ Exeunt, L.2.E., waltzing. Enter Bess, R.U.E., crosses and looks off, L. ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Poor Alec! He doesn't dare to come out of the box! I wonder where Judge Knox is? There he is! Oh, he fell down!
[ Enter Cruger, L.2.E., followed by Creighton, both laughing, and looking back after Knox ]

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Poor Knox!

sp.speaker: Creigh.
sp.stage: Crosses R., in front of Cruger, L.C., laughing
sp.p: Why didn't you tell him?

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p:
He wouldn't let me. This is my second attempt to reach the smoking room. Come, Creighton, you like a good cigar.
[ Enter Dick, L.U.E., looking back ]

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
She came towards me just now and I pretended not to see her.
[ Comes down, L. ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Oh, look at you "Three Bonanzas!" I've an idea. Kitty Ives made a lot of money the other night, at the "Orthopaedic Ball," selling flowers for charity. There's a poor family named Matheson. The father's very ill. I told them all about the Charity Ball, and tomorrow I want to take them something — just a little memento of it.

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: And you mean to raise it by selling a dance?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Um, um. How much will you give?

sp.speaker: Creigh.
sp.p: Twenty dollars!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Twenty-five!

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: How much will you give, Dick?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: For a dance with you, Bess? Fifty!

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Oh, let's have a regular auction.
[ Creighton goes up, gets a chair, brings it down, C., for Bess. He then comes down ]

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.stage: Enters, R.U.E. Goes down, R., to Cruger ]
sp.p: While I was sitting in Box L., waiting, who should come in but auntie and Judge Knox. She was trying to persuade him to continue dancing, but he wouldn't!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Alec, I'm afraid it's going to be more difficult to get you out of this scrape than I thought!

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
I told Mr. John Van Buren. He's gone to Box L. now to explain to the judge. Oh, if I ever get out of this, I'll go to Sunday School. Hello! What's up?
[ Crosses to R. of Bess ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Selling a dance for charity, Alec! Last bid, fifty dollars! How much will you give? Fifty — fifty —
[ Stop music ]

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: I don't know whether I'll be spared to dance it, but, fifty-one.

sp.speaker: Creigh.
sp.p: Fifty-two.

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Fifty-three!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Fifty-four.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Oh, isn't it jolly! Fifty-four — four — four —

sp.speaker: Creigh.
sp.p: Fifty-five.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Sixty!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Sixty-five!

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: These monarchs represent millions! What show do I stand?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Sixty-five — and a five — and a five —

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: I must have that dance!

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: This is exciting! Sixty-five!

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Hold the bid open till I strike auntie!

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Bid now!

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: I've got one share of B. and O., worth sixty-eight on the street today. Be worth forty-eight tomorrow. I'll unload to auntie tonight!

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Come, gentlemen, sixty-five — sixty-five —

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: And a half!

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: An 'alf, an 'alf!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Sixty-six!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Seventy!

sp.speaker: Creigh.
sp.p: Seventy-five!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Eighty!

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
I'll hock my camera, but I'll have that dance!
[ Aloud ]
Eighty-five!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: I bid ninety!

sp.speaker: Creigh.
sp.p: I bid ninety-five!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: I bid one hundred!

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
I bid — Good-evening.
[ They all start up ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
Stay, Alec, I'll buy it for you! Alec Robinson bids one hundred and fifty dollars!
[ Dick up C. and Alec, L. Creighton up to Dick ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: Who has kept bids going, through dialogue, with grand flourish, brings sale to sudden end, before Cruger and Creighton can bid. Enter John Van Buren, L.U.E., goes to Bess
sp.p:
Sold to Alexander Robinson for one hundred and fifty. Brother John!
[ Jumps down from chair and runs off, L.2.E. Everybody laughs ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: I seem to have caused a panic with the auctioneer! What has gone to Alec Robinson for one hundred and fifty dollars?

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: She was selling a dance for the benefit of some poor family — Matheson, I think the name was.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Then they'll need the money sooner than she thinks! When I called, this afternoon, the father was very sick.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: I'm afraid to ask him what happened in Box L.

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Well, I'm glad to find you here. It isn't every clergyman that would appear at the Charity Ball.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: It would be a strange sort of charity that a clergyman could not countenance! It is sufficient to me that the good women of our land are at the head of the work.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Mr. Van Buren, you've given the ladies a grand send-off! I think you could move anybody. Did — di — did you — touch the judge's heart?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Oh, yes. He was so glad to hear it wasn't true, that he forgave you at once.
[ Looking off ]
But he's coming this way. He'll tell you himself!

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
No — I think not — tonight. I'll let him alone for a few days.
[ Exit, hastily, R.2.E. John goes up, laughing ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: She is without a flaw.

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Well, I would have told you that —

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: But you took precious good care not to!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p:
At least, permit me to congratulate you upon the additional member of your family.
[ Warn music ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
Cruger, bah! John, if I had received the information from anyone but you, I should annihilate the young hoaxer!
[ Enter Mrs. De Peyster, L.1.E., crosses to Judge ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Judge, after your fall, you remained in Box L. so long that I became alarmed!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Oh, forgive me! Allow me to make amends! Put me down for every dance left on your card!

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p:
Oh, no. It might affect you as the waltz did!
[ Music ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
Oh, I feel better now. I feel as if I could indulge in a Highland Fling!
[ Dancing ]
Tee-de-de-de —

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p:
O judge, I beg of you!
[ Judge crosses to L.C. in front of Mrs. De Peyster ]

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: Jubilant, isn't he?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
I feel as buoyant as a cargo of cork!
[ Glaring at Cruger ]
With "emphasis" on the cork!
[ Exeunt Judge and Mrs. De Peyster, L.2.E. After their exit, Dick starts to come down, nearly faints, falling against lower C. arch. John goes to him and brings him down. Creighton places chair for him to sit. Cruger goes back, R., of Dick ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Dick! Dick!

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Creigh.
sp.stage: L. of Dick. Has followed John up to him, and assists him downstage
sp.p:
Shall I get a doctor?
[ Goes L. ]

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Doctor? No! Can't a man seek a breath of fresh air without a doctor?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: I think I had better get one!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.stage: Starting to his feet and crossing down, C.
sp.p:
No, no, I say! I'm engaged to Miss Cruger for the next dance, and I mean to dance it!
[ John puts back chair and comes down, L. of Dick. Creighton goes R. Cruger, R. of Dick ]

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p: You'll have to be more careful, Dick, or that little scheme of ours will never be consummated.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: It will, Mr. Cruger — it will! And I'll begin my part of it tonight.

sp.speaker: Cruger .
sp.p:
Well, I wish you luck! You'll have to get a doctor for me if I don't get a smoke soon! Come, Creighton, come!
[ Exit Cruger, followed by Creighton, R.2.E. ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: You ought not to be here tonight.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
This is — nothing!
[ Intensely ]
Today's work with Cruger was worth it!
[ Shakes with intensity of feelings ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: See how it has shattered your nerves, blanched your face! Why, Dick, I'm only thirty-five and you are twice my age, at thirty-two.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
Nonsense, old fellow! You're wrong!
[ Holding out his hand ]
Look. No shattered nerves there. I wish I could make you understand how different your work is from mine! Why don't you let me have my own way?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Because you are taking from me the companion who never had a joy or sorrow that his brother did not share.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: We are not boys now. What do you want me to do?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Give me back my brother Dick!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: I shall soon rid you of anxiety. I am to become Franklin Cruger's son-in-law.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: You marry Ann Cruger?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Yes. Why shouldn't I?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Christmas night, I found you in your room, with your head bowed upon a letter. You told me it was from a woman that you loved. Was it from Ann Cruger?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Yet, you speak of marriage with her.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Men in my position cannot consult their hearts.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: And what will become of that other woman?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Oh, she'll get over it.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Dick. You love her, and she — God help her — loves you.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: I — I — won't talk about her —

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: In this race for supremacy, you don't even stop at the breaking of a human heart!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
John!
[ Enter Phyllis, L.2.E. Goes to L. of John ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Where is that woman now?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p:
Mr. Van Buren —
[ Sees Dick and stops ]

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Miss Lee!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Well, I declare! Living under the same roof and you hardly know each other! Dick, I blame you for that!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
I regret that I have not been able to visit my home as much as I should wish since Miss Lee came here.
[ Crosses, L. ]
I must return to the ballroom. You will excuse me.
[ Bows, and exit, L.2.E. Phyllis, disappointed look ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
That look that was in her face the day I first saw her!
[ To Phyllis ]
I hope I did right in asking you to come tonight?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Don't think me ungrateful, Mr. Van Buren. I realize how patient you have been with me.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: More than once, of late, I've noticed that you are troubled about something. Why, even now, there is a frightened look on your face. What have you to fear?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p:
I try to feel there is nothing to fear — but —
[ Goes L., looks off, L., after Dick ]
Oh, but I can't!
[ Downstage ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Do you fear the future, when I tell you that nothing shall harm you?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Even when you tell me!

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Brother John, there's a messenger for you, from Mrs. Matheson. He's waiting in the corridor.
[ Enter Ann, R.2.E. Goes to John ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
I'm afraid her husband must be worse. Ann, won't you remain with Miss Lee? I sha'n't be long.
[ Aside ]
You couldn't have come at a more opportune moment.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Mr. Van Buren, as it will be late when you return, I suppose there will be no lamp in the window tonight?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.stage: Going to Phyllis. Ann joins Bess ]
sp.p:
Misery keeps all sorts of hours. Never a night passes that I don't put my lamp in its place. Some unfortunate who needs my help may see it, and know that the door is open, and I am waiting.
[ Phyllis turns upstage. To Ann ]
There is a sorrow in her life that she will not tell me. You speak to her for my sake. Come, Bessie!
[ Exit, R.2.E. with Bess ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Well. This is delightful!

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: He does not come because I am here.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
I suppose I must play the hypocrite.
[ Phyllis goes down, L., to chair, and clutches it to support herself. Ann goes to Phyllis ]
Why, what's the matter?
[ Stop music ]

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Don't mind me!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
You are faint. Sit here!
[ Places chair, C. ]

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: You are so kind!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
Are you better?
[ Crossing, L., in front of Phyllis ]
Shall we go back to the ballroom?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: No, I can't go back there.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: O Miss Cruger, I can tell you. You will help me.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Why, Miss Lee, in what do you need my help?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: I know of a woman who came into a house where everything was done for her that loving hearts could suggest. She made them believe she was worthy of their love when she was not. Now, she wants to tell the truth.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Why does she not?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: She is afraid!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Of their condemnation?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Of their pain at learning how they have been deceived.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Did this woman confide in you?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Yes. Those whom she is deceiving trust her implicitly; yet I allow her to remain among them. What would you do in my place?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
I must know more about her.
[ Goes R. ]

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: She wants to confide in you. There is no one else whom she can go to. She is utterly helpless, without a home, or friends.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Alone?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Except for the man who said he loved her.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Why does he not protect her?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p:
O God!
[ Warn music ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: A broken promise!

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Yes. She knows it now.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.stage: Half suspicious, fixed look at Phyllis ]
sp.p: You seem to take her case very much to heart.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: So would you, if you knew how much she had suffered.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Tomorrow, you shall take me to her.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: She is here tonight.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Here! Oh, be prudent! For, if the people in that ballroom knew of this woman in their midst, penitent though she be —

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Would they not have mercy?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Oh, I am afraid to answer! We open our purses and give our gold to the unfortunate! But when we are asked to open our hearts and give our sympathy to some poor creature who has erred — Ah! then we draw back! Our charity stays at home, locked up in our selfish hearts. But there is one person to whom this woman can go for help.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: And that one?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: John Van Buren!

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Oh, it is he that has been deceived!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: John Van Buren!

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Yes!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: And the woman?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Myself.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: You are not like the rest of the world.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: And this is the woman he loves!

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.stage: Trying to take Ann's hand, kneels ]
sp.p: Help me!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.stage: Crossing, L. Phyllis rises, to R.C., up ]
sp.p: Don't! Don't touch me! There is no place here for you. I told you what we were, and I am no better than the rest.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p:
Let me go. Let me go.
[ Enter Dick, L.2.E. ]

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
I have come to claim you.
[ Phyllis, at the sound of Dick's voice, stops; Dick, seeing her, stops ]
Ann, have you forgotten your dance?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Dick, will you not excuse me?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
Certainly, if you wish. It's hard to give up my dance, but I suppose I must be content and ask pardon for intruding.
[ About to withdraw, L. ]

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.stage: Forgetting herself and starting to him ]
sp.p:
Dick!
[ Ann, amazed, starts. Dick stops. Phyllis, realizing her mistake, stands motionless ]

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Did you call me, Miss Lee?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: No. I — I — I — forgot!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: You appear to be in some trouble?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: She is.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Have you and Miss Lee been exchanging confidences?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: She has placed in my keeping the holiest confidence that one woman can give to another.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: But she guards, with a woman's devotion, the name of him who should have given her a place among his own.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
I appreciate your motive in making me the recipient of this intelligence, and I infer that she will henceforth cease to make the rectory her home.
[ Warn curtain. Ann makes movement toward him as though to speak ]
You wish some explanation to be made of Miss Lee's departure that will at once be generous to her and merciful to those among whom she has lived. I will render any service in my power.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
Then tell your brother that I have persuaded Miss Lee to come with me tonight to my home.
[ Phyllis goes to Ann ]
As Ann Cruger's friend, her departure from the rectory needs no explanation.
[ Ann embraces Phyllis. Dick bows, turns, exit, L. ]

div.head: ACT III.
div.stage: Scene : The study at the rectory. "In the watches of the night." A soft somber light relieves the darkness of the room. The cold gray light of a winter's night comes through the stained glass windows at the back. Lamp used by Betts in Act I on the table, L.C., burning low. During the progress of this act an air of stillness must pervade the stage. House lights down low as possible. Foots and borders out. Ten seconds after curtain rises, distant sleigh bells heard, gradually drawing nearer until sleigh stops, L.
Discovered : At rise of curtain Sophie enters, L.1.E., with candle. Stage lights go up a trifle. Sophie puts candle on table and goes R.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Good night, Mrs. De Peyster, much obliged.

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P.
sp.p: Good night, my dear.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Good night, Judge Knox.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Good night, little one.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Good night, Bess, pleasant dreams.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Same to you, Alec. Good night.
[ Sophie opens door, R.U.E. Sleigh heard to drive off, and the sound to die away in the distance ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. De P., Judge , Alec , Bess .
sp.p:
Good night.
[ Bess enters, R.U.E., wrapped in furs, runs to the fire ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Thanks, Sophie, close the door quick. B-r-r-r.
[ Sitting before fire. Sophie closes door and comes to her ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Is that you, Bess?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Why, angel, are you up?
[ During this Bess is seated in armchair by fire, and Sophie, kneeling beside her, takes off her overshoes and leggings ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Do you think I could go to bed and you not at home? Didn't your brother John come with you?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: No. He was called away quite early, and he left me in charge of Mrs. De Peyster. I came home with an engaged couple.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Oh, then Judge Knox was with you?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Um — um. And Alec —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p:
Phyllis, what makes you so silent tonight?
[ A second's pause ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Phyllis isn't here, angel.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Not here? Where is she then?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
She went home with Ann Cruger. They left before we did.
[ Jumping up from chair and giving Sophie her opera cloak ]
Take 'em upstairs, Sophie. Oh, I've had such a lovely time.
[ Exit Sophie, L.2.E., upstairs ]
There's brother John now.
[ Runs to balustrade ]
Angel, here's brother John. Wait for me a minute. I've something very important to tell him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Can't you wait till morning?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: No, it won't keep.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Very well. Very well.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
I just couldn't sleep if I didn't tell 'em both I was engaged to Alec.
[ Enter John, R.2.E. He wears a cape overcoat and high hat, both of which are slightly covered with snow ]
Brother John.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.stage: Removes coat and hat which he places on chair, R.C.
sp.p: Why, Bess, you here?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Yes, brother John. I wanted to tell you something. Ann sent word to you that Phyllis was going to spend the night with her.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: She went home with Ann?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Yes. So you were not to expect her at the rectory. And, brother John, there's something else I want to tell you. If you approve, angel is sure to.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Oh. You want to fix matters with me first, eh?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: If you please, brother John. It's so much easier to win your big brother over than it is your little mother.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.stage: Taking her face between his hands ]
sp.p: Well, what mischief have you been up to?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Been getting engaged.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Engaged?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Um-um.
[ Shyly ]
In a sort of a kind of a way, you know — Alec and I have been planning tonight how we'd arrange matters when we were married.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Indeed. You've gone as far as that?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Couldn't go any further till we saw you and angel.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Yes, yes. But you are both so young.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Oh, we'll outgrow that. Brother John, Alec wants to give me an engagement ring. You'll let him, won't you? Say yes, and this will be the happiest moment I've ever lived.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: I remember you said the same thing the day when you put on your first long dress.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: But that dress just revolutionized me.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Go, nestle that little head on your mother's breast — tell her of your love. Listen to what she says. This is one of the cases where the little mother can give better advice than the big brother.
[ Kisses her ]
Go to her.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Brother John.
[ He comes to her. She kisses him and turns and speaks ]
I thought it was great fun getting engaged. But it isn't.
[ Making a wry face ]
I want to cr — cry.
[ Exit, L.1.E. ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
What is sweeter to hear than a young girl's first confession of her love!
[ John turns up lamp on table, C., and places it in alcove window, back. Church clock strikes two. He comes to bookcase and is about to take down book, when there is heard a knock at the chapel door, R.2.E. ]
Come in.
[ Enter Betts, R.2.E., wrapped in overcoat and huge comforter slightly covered with snow. John takes book and sits behind table, C. ]

sp.speaker: Betts .
sp.p:
"Out in the cold world, out in the street." Pretty severe storm this, Mr. Van Buren. Thought I would go to my room this way. Little shorter than through the parish buildings. Been playing chess for the last two hours with old Joe Randolph. He's a good player, but, lor! — he can't hold a candle to me. We had a spirited argument about a certain move which we
agreed to leave to you. You see my king's pawn tried to take his king's castle. By the way, how did you leave Matheson?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: He died about an hour ago!

sp.speaker: Betts .
sp.p: God bless me! He was a good chess player. What in the world his poor wife will do, I don't know — with all those little children on her hands.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Something must be done for them. Come to me in the morning, Betts. I shall have something for you to do.

sp.speaker: Betts .
sp.p: All right, sir, good night.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Good night, Betts.

sp.speaker: Betts .
sp.stage: Going toward chapel door, R.3.E., steps inside
sp.p:
Everybody thinks I'm the most charitable man in New York. It's all him.
[ At door ]
Shall I disturb you if I practise an anthem or two?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Now, how many times a week do you want me to answer that question? Betts, when do you sleep? Morning, noon, and night you seem to be at that organ.

sp.speaker: Betts .
sp.p: Why, sir, it's part of me. Nearly forty years since I played the first anthem on it. Think of the joy and sorrow it has accompanied in that time. It's a living thing. My wife, my son, and my little girl used to listen to it. Somehow, it seems to bring me nearer to them.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Ah — old friend. Many a time has your uncomplaining nature taught me how to endure.

sp.speaker: Betts .
sp.p: Sure it doesn't disturb you?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Its tones are always soothing to me, and tonight, more than ever, I want to hear them.

sp.speaker: Betts .
sp.p:
"No one to love, no one to caress."
[ Exit, R.3.E., singing to himself as he goes out ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
How hard it is snowing. When I think of my loved ones sheltered from harm, how I pity any poor creatures who may be out in such a storm.
[ Comes down, R. Looking off, L.1.E. ]
They've all retired. I could almost have asked Betts to remain here with me. I have such a feeling of unrest. Except for the storm outside, everything is still. And yet the very stillness of the room speaks a nameless dread. The shadows from the firelight seem to shape themselves into shapes of warning — all pointing to me. I fear no foe; why should thoughts like these oppress me —
[ Leans back, supporting himself with both hands upon the table. The soft tones of the organ are heard. Lights small taper from the candle, then extinguishes candle ]
I will go into the church and, in the chancel where I offer up the sacrifice of praise and thanksgiving before my congregation, I will pour out my heart — alone —
[ Ascends stairs, R.U.E. As John reaches the first landing, there is heard a tapping at the window. He pauses, his face towards the room, and listens. He then ascends the steps to the second landing. Meanwhile, at the window the white face of Phyllis is seen, as she leans against the window frame for support. She is still in her ball dress, her wrap thrown over her, the snow falling on her partly uncovered head ]

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Mr. Van Buren, Mr. Van Buren.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.stage: Stops on the second landing and listens intently
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Mr. Van Buren.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Is it fancy that changes the sound of the organ into the tones of a voice calling upon me?
[ Hearing nothing more, he turns and passes into the church. The darkness of the room increases as his light disappears. Phyllis leaves the window. A moment later the door, R.2.E., is opened and she staggers into the room, closes the door by falling back against it, her arms extended, clutching the portières ]

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p:
You told me, when my cross was heavier than I could bear, to come to you. It is — it is —
[ Phyllis sinks down at the steps; as she lies sobbing, the sound of the organ dies away. A moment's silence, broken only by an occasional sob from Phyllis. John reappears with light ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
I thought I heard a cry coming from this room.
[ Phyllis utters a lour, plaintive moan ]
Again.
[ Starts to descend when a low moan causes him to pause on the second landing ]
Someone is here.
[ He is coming down when a sob at his feet stops him. He holds the light aloft as he looks down ]
A woman.
[ He places the light in a niche at his L., and bends over her ]
Some unfortunate who needs my help.
[ Gently raising her, her head resting on his breast so he cannot see her face ]
My poor child, what trouble has brought you to me — a night like this? Oh, how cold you are. Come to the fire.
[ As they reach the spot where the light from the fireplace falls into the room, she raises her head and looks up into his face ]
Phyllis! What is the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: I have come to tell you now what I should have confessed at first.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.stage: Hardly able to speak the words ]
sp.p: You come to me — at such an hour — to tell me — what?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: I — I —

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Speak.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p:
Oh, I want to die.
[ Sinking at his feet ]
I want to die.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
To die. Then I was not mistaken. The look I saw in your face the day you knelt by your father's bedside — the same that met my sight yesterday in the church — and again in the ballroom — tonight. I knew there was a grief you were trying to tell me, but what can it be that brings you to me like this?
[ At this moment the door, R., is quickly opened and Ann Cruger enters. She is still in her ball dress though warmly enveloped in her cloak. Ann, at sight of Phyllis kneeling before John, gives a half inaudible cry of despair ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: John.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Ann.
[ John turns quickly and lights candle on table ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.stage: Going to Phyllis and sinking down beside her, takes her in her arms
sp.p: Phyllis. We had just arrived home. I went to prepare her room myself, and when I came downstairs, she had gone. Through this terrible storm she has walked here, John. What has she said to you?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
Thank God!
[ Aloud ]
Phyllis, dear, come home with me.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: No — no.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: John, you placed her in my care. She is not herself. You asked me to be her friend. I beg of you to be guided by me. Let me take her home.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: There is something she wants to tell me.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: She must not. You cannot help her. I may yet find the way. John, there are times in our lives when our faith in those we trust must be absolute. Such a time has come to you and me now. Trust me and let me take her with me.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: It is only of myself that I will speak.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Oh! And it was I who told her to come to him.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Let me tell him.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: I am listening.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Wait until tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: No — no.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: John, not tonight — not tonight.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Why not tonight? She comes to me at this hour. I find her prostrate upon these steps. I hear sobs that can only come from a breaking heart. I am God's minister. Why wait until tomorrow when a heart is breaking tonight?
[ Bending over her ]
Come.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: No. Let me stay as I am.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: If it were anyone but you, I should believe that only one misfortune could bow you in the dust like this.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.stage: Slowly, raising her eyes to his ]
sp.p: Believe it of me.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.stage: Extending his hand as though to keep back any further words she may utter
sp.p:
No.
[ For a moment he stands appalled, his eyes fixed upon hers. As the truth dawns upon him, he raises his eyes reverently. For a moment he looks in front of him with a dull, dead stare. Then, with a cry of pain, he suddenly buries his face in his hands, turning his back to the audience ]
Oh!

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p:
What must you think of me? Do not spare me. Nothing that you can say will be as bitter as what I have said to myself every day since I have been here.
[ At this moment the organ is heard playing softly the prelude to the anthem. Phyllis, after a slight pause, turns to Ann ]
I thought it would all come right. I believed so in him, and I waited — waited —

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Phyllis.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: What is left for me now?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Hands that will uphold you. Hearts that will enfold you in their love.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p:
Everybody will despise me.
[ Betts is heard singing the words, "He was despised" ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: My arms are open to you.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p:
They will turn me from their doors.
[ Betts heard singing, "Despised and rejected" ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
My home shall be yours.
[ Ann has slowly raised her head, listening to the anthem ]
Because one man has been pitiless, do you think He who reads our hearts will not see all that is pure in yours?
[ John turns towards them, his face grief-stricken, his eyes bent sadly on Phyllis ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Phyllis, tell me. The one to whom you gave your heart — ?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: I am his until I die. Even beyond the grave he will have my love.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Then all may yet be right. It must be! No man can be indifferent to such a love. How deep that love is, he shall learn from me.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: No longer the man you have known. Nor even the priest. It is your brother who speaks to you now. I will meet him face to face, and make him render an account to me.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
John, are you there?
[ Phyllis gives a half-stifled cry. Ann rises with a look of terror ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Don't be alarmed. It is only my brother Dick.
[ Crosses to L. ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
Not a word.
[ With forced calmness ]
John, shall I take her with me now?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: John, are you in the study?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Yes, I am here.
[ At sound of John's voice, Dick stops outside door ]

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Oh! Just a moment with mother. Then I want to talk to you.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: I shall be here.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
Come, Phyllis.
[ To John ]
It is late and she needs rest.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Before she goes, there is something else left for her to tell me — his name.
[ Dead pause ]

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Don't let me say any more. I should have gone away and buried my sorrow, where none of you could have seen me again.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Has not the hardest part been told?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: John, I beg of you, don't question her any more.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Do you know?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Does Phyllis remember when I stood by the bed of her dying father? He took my hand and, with his other placed upon your head even as mine is now, said, "I have no one to leave my little girl to — will you take care of her?" Do you remember what I replied? In this, your hour of need, will you not let me keep my promise?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Yes. You will plead with him as I cannot. He will listen to you. I won't believe he doesn't love me. His cruel words tonight —

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Tonight? You saw him tonight?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: In that ballroom?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Yes. Yes.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Do I know him?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Oh, and I am powerless.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Phyllis, tell me.
[ Phyllis, with bowed head, signifies "Yes" ]
I know him? Who is he?
[ After a pause ]
Who is he?
[ Phyllis slowly raises her head as if to speak ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.stage: With a cry, turns quickly to Phyllis, and presses her lips to those of Phyllis for a long kiss ]
sp.p: Phyllis.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.stage: After a slight pause, turning, R. ]
sp.p:
Take me away. Don't let me say any more.
[ With Ann goes to chair, R. ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Why did you not let her speak?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: What you want her to say will bring pain —

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
To whom?
[ Ann raises her head, with a look of supplication, to John ]
What is it you both know and are trying to keep from me?
[ Looks towards the door at which Dick's voice was heard. Then at the two women. Pause ]
Phyllis, you are not strong enough at present to return home with Ann.
[ Taking her hand and leading her to R.3.E. ]
I want you to rest here a moment.
[ Exit Phyllis. He closes door and turns to Ann, who has gotten round to back of table. Organ heard ]
If anyone can make this blow less bitter, Ann, you are that one. Speak —

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: I cannot — oh, I cannot.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Because it is my brother!
[ Ann, unable to reply, bows her head on her breast. With a groan, he falls into chair, his arms extended across table ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
John!
[ Kneeling by his side, tearfully ]
If I could only suffer for you!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.stage: His arm around her as she looks wistfully into his face
sp.p:
Always faithful. When days are darkest, you are closest to my side. Whenever affliction comes, you are near to soothe and comfort. You tried so hard to spare me. God reward you!
[ Pointing to chapel, R.3.E. ]
Go to her.
[ Ann goes toward R.3.E. ]

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha, ha! No fear. I'll not keep him up long.
[ John rises and stands with his eyes fixed on L.1.E. ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: John, remember he is your brother.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.stage: Immovable, his eyes fixed on the door ]
sp.p:
I shall not forget that she loves him. But close the door and do not interrupt us.
[ Almost in a whisper ]
Go.
[ Ann, with a look of fear, goes out, R.3.E., and the door is heard to close. Enter Dick, L.1.E. His manner is light and careless and his face slightly flushed with wine. He must not show the least sign of intoxication, his condition simply being that of a man exhilarated from drinking several glasses of wine ]

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
Hello, John. Mother didn't want me to keep you up. Why, you are as great a night owl as I am.
[ Comes down and brings a chair from up L. down to L. of table ]
I've been at the club. I knew I couldn't sleep. Saw your light in the window. You keep it for the unfortunate. Well, here I am!
[ Throwing himself in chair, L. of table ]
Been in bad luck tonight.
[ With dogged firmness, bringing his hand down on table ]
But I'll pull through.
[ Suddenly stopping and looking up, then laughs ]
There, old fellow. You don't know what I'm talking about. That affair concerning Ann Cruger. I've had a little setback. But her father and I had a talk after we left the Opera House. As a man of the world, he understands. Come, John, be sociable. If I didn't have you to come to sometimes — do you know, there's nothing quiets me like one of those old-time talks with you.
[ Looking vacantly before him ]
I think you're right, old fellow. "The game isn't worth the candle." Some nights, after I've been stirring things up in that cauldron downtown, I come back here —
[ Suddenly changing ]
Oh, if I'm not careful, I'll end in Bloomingdale. There's only one way out of it. It will all end the day I stand before St. Mildred's chancel rail and hear you speak the words that will make Ann Cruger my wife.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.stage: Who, during the above, has remained motionless, his eyes fixed on Dick
sp.p: I would sooner speak the words that consign your body to the grave.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
John, what's the matter with you? What are you looking at me in that way for?
[ Rising ]
Brother!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Take it back. No one shall call me brother whom I call scoundrel.
[ Fist on table ]

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: John!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Shall I tell you why you cannot sleep? Why you try to drown your thoughts in dissipation at your club? Because you cannot think of the man we both called father and look at what you have done.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: You've discovered who the woman is —

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Yes, the woman to whom I gave shelter under this roof — and yet you said nothing.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: My interests demanded that I give her up. And I did. I am no better than the rest of men. There's no use talking about it now. With Cruger's assistance, I mean to marry his daughter.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: The world condemns a woman for one fault, yet permits a man to wreck a human life. And still thinks him worthy to offer himself in marriage to another.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: John, you've said enough. What right have you to call me to account?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Stop!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: You say I'm not to call you brother. What are you, then, that I should listen?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Conscience — since yours is dead — a conscience against which you need not try to close your ears, for I will cry with a voice so loud that, though you shut yourself in vaults of steel and fortify yourself with mountains of gold, I will pierce them all until I reach your heart.
[ Dick starts towards L. ]
Before you cross the threshold of that door, I want a promise.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: What promise?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: That you will make Phyllis Lee your wife.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Impossible.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: She came to the house of God for refuge. Her minister will see that grace is done her.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
I've determined what to do, and nothing can change me.
[ Goes down, L.C. ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Then I put aside my calling — all kinship between us — and stand before you man to man. Will you make Phyllis Lee your wife?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Do you know what that refusal means to her?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Since you care so much for her yourself —

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Don't say it —

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: If you love her —

sp.speaker: John .
sp.stage: Angrily, raising his arm to strike him ]
sp.p: You —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p:
Boys!
[ John gradually lowers his hand ]
Boys!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
I now see the wisdom of God in permitting her to be blind. She cannot see the shame stamped upon your face.
[ Mrs. Van Buren appears, L.1.E. Dick goes to chair by fire ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: My boys, do you know what time it is? Almost three o'clock. You bring your old mother to you just as you used to when you were little fellows, and would lie awake and talk until I came to stop you. Ah, you may be grown men to others, but you are still my boys. Now, which of you shall I punish for keeping the other up so late? It's Dick's fault, I'm sure. Do you remember, John, one night before the Fourth of July, when Dick put a large firecracker under your bed and set it off? And when everybody in the house rushed up to your room to see what on earth had happened, you in the middle of the room, frightened out of your wits, and the little rogue in bed pretending to be fast asleep. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: We were boys then, mother.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Yes, my coming here tonight, to make you both go to bed, brings it all back to me. Dick, where are you?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.stage: With forced laugh, crossing to her ]
sp.p: Here, mother, here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: You were so quiet. I didn't know but that something was the matter.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: No, no — mother, dear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p:
Well, I'll kiss you both good night.
[ Kisses Dick, then John, who comes to her ]
O John, have you been telling Dick about Bess?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.stage: Crosses back to table, C., with an effort at calmness
sp.p: No — no —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p:
Well, then, I'll tell him. Dick, it seems that Bess —
[ Bess's head appears from between the folds of the portières, L.1.E. ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: O angel, please let me tell him —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: What! You downstairs?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: Comes down steps. She has on a dainty little night wrapper
sp.p:
Yes. I couldn't sleep. I don't think I'll ever sleep again. I heard Dick's voice and I couldn't keep under the bedclothes.
[ Comes down to Dick who sits in armchair before fireplace. Sits on his lap affectionately ]
Dick, did you think I could tell all the others and forget you? Dick, I'm going to be a bride — a real one. I told brother John, and he sent me to angel. I didn't come to you
because I knew anything I wanted, you'd let me have — even if it were a husband. Guess whom I'm engaged to?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Alec Robinson.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Somebody told you!
[ Pointing ]
Now, brother John, you've been telling him about it all this time.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: No, dear, we've been speaking of something quite different.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Well, angel says, when we are older, she sees no obstacle to our marriage.
[ Sighs ]
She thinks it will be about five years. My, that's a long time! But Alec's worth the delay.
[ Sinks on knees ]
And I'm so happy.
[ Dreamily ]
Just think what it is to a young girl who loves someone with all her heart and soul — to have him take her to a nice little home — all their own — and call her his wife.
[ Feelingly ]
O Dick, if you only knew what that means to a woman! Congratulate me, Dick.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.stage: Who has listened impassively, draws her tenderly to him
sp.p:
I do, little one.
[ Kisses her ]
I do.
[ Bess goes to John ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
May no tears ever dim these eyes except such as we shed in sympathy for those less fortunate than you are. God bless you, darling. There — run along with angel.
[ Bess goes out, L.1.E., with Mrs. Van Buren. John approaches Dick, who is still seated in chair, and stands behind him ]
Tonight I have heard two confessions of love in this room — one from Phyllis Lee, the other from our little Bess.
[ At the moment Dick shows that his sister's words have moved him. John observes this and tenderly places his hand on Dick's shoulder ]
Suppose someone dealt with our sister as you are dealing with Phyllis Lee?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
O God!
[ Dick, with a cry of horror, starts to his feet, instinctively clenching his fists. Then, with a sob, falls back into the chair, utterly broken ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
If I have lost the power to plead with you, let her innocent tongue speak for me. Not as the man now, but as your brother once more, I beg, I implore, do what is right. Give me your hand. Be my brother Dick again.
[ Dick slowly rises, goes to John and takes his outstretched hand ]
Give me that promise!

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: You will make Phyllis Lee your wife?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Not because I want you to, but because your heart turns of itself towards the woman over whose letter I found you that night with bowed head?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
Yes.
[ John presses his hand and goes to chapel door which he quietly opens. The low sobbing of a woman is heard. Listening ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Phyllis.
[ Calling ]
Ann.
[ Ann appears at door, R.3.E., looks at John, reads the truth in his face, then retires to the chapel. In a moment Phyllis appears ]
Phyllis, my brother has something to say to you.
[ He goes L., the firelight falling strongly on his face. Ann appears at door, R.3.E. Phyllis has come forward, R.C. ]

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
Phyllis, is there love enough left in your heart for me, to forgive all the misery I have caused you?
[ Phyllis turning to him wistfully ]
Not yet, not yet. I could better hear your reproaches than what you are about to say. False to myself, false to those at home, false to you, I come with my eyes open at last. Phyllis, I want you to be my wife.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: O Dick. You do love me, then?

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p:
Yes.
[ Dick's head gently sinks upon her shoulder ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.stage: Comes to C., front of table
sp.p: One thing more. She will return with Ann tonight. Let her bear your name.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: Whenever you will.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Now.

sp.speaker: Dick .
sp.p: And the words that will make her — my wife?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.stage: Approaching the table, placing his hand on the prayer book
sp.p: I will — speak — them.

div.head: ACT IV.
div.stage: Scene : The sitting room. Same as Act I. Afternoon of Memorial Day, 1889. Where the trees and vines in Act I were bare, foliage is now seen through the window. The rays of the setting sun come into the room through the open window .

Discovered : Betts seated in alcove, up L., chess board on lap with chess. On stand by him lies a newspaper containing a chess problem, in which he is rapt. Moving a piece, he hums, pleased; he takes back the move and is silent while he ponders. Mrs. Van Buren coming downstairs, R.3.E.

sp.speaker: Betts .
sp.p: The most difficult problem I ever found in a newspaper, and I've been working the chess columns for years.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Still on the problem, Mr. Betts?

sp.speaker: Betts .
sp.p: Joe Randolph and I work 'em out together and divide the prize. Joe makes his living at it.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.stage: Enters, L.2.E., with wreath of flowers on tray. Coming down
sp.p: Mother.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: My daughter. After our drive Bess and I called upon Ann. The steamer didn't reach quarantine till late last night, so she couldn't get home till this morning.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: She must be very anxious to see the rectory once more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p:
I feel as if my own child had come back to me. Eighteen months since she went away — two weeks after your marriage.
[ To sofa, R. ]

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p:
Yes.
[ Down L. ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: I shall never forget that night after the Charity Ball, when Ann came upstairs to my room and told me that early the next morning Dick had to go away and that you and he had arranged to be married that night. To think that you and Dick loved each other and I didn't know it! It was only after John pronounced you man and wife, and Ann made everything clear to me, that I recovered from my surprise. But what detains Bess?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Didn't she come in with you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: No. She went up to the corner to see Judge Knox's regiment pass by. She said the parade today was beautiful. Dick used to be her companion always on Memorial Day. My boy!

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: You were very proud of him, were you not, mother?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Yes, but that unconquerable spirit of his always caused me anxiety. He was always first in every undertaking, until the day he made the whole business world acknowledge him its master.

sp.speaker: Betts .
sp.p:
And that night he dropped down on his office floor — dead.
[ Continues his game ]

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: A year and three months since he was taken from me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Why, you've been cutting some flowers.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: I am making a wreath.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Every week has its Memorial Day for you. But, though a whole nation mingles its tears today, it strews its flowers of hope; so let us keep in the sunlight, not in the shadow.

sp.speaker: Betts .
sp.p: I've done it!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Solved the problem, Mr. Betts?

sp.speaker: Betts .
sp.stage: Gathering up the pieces, hat, and chess board, and starting to go, R.
sp.p:
Exactly what I've done. Wager Joe Randolph hasn't come anywhere near it. I'll go show him how to do it.
[ Chuckling ]

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Mr. Betts, you told me this morning you would postpone your visit to Woodlawn until the day had grown quiet.

sp.speaker: Betts .
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p:
Will you see me before you go?
[ Betts nods assent and, with chess board under his arm, exit, R.C., humming "See the conquering hero comes." Phyllis crosses to piano and plays a low, sweet air. Bess, laughing, runs on, C. from R. ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Judge Knox looks just magnificent on his black charger in his colonel's uniform. If I were the enemy — well, I wouldn't have the heart to shoot a sight like that. Mrs. Knox passed him in her victoria. The judge made his horse prance, and saluted her; and she waved her handkerchief frantically. Ha, ha, ha! Such fun!

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Alec belongs to the same regiment, doesn't he?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: Rising, with a sudden change of manner, her chin in air
sp.p: You mean Mr. Robinson? I believe he does.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Mr. Robinson! Oh!

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: There has been a little difficulty between you — and — Mr. Robinson?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: With a toss of her head
sp.p: An insurmountable difficulty. Angel and Phyllis, you will oblige me by not alluding to that person in my presence again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Then you're not in the same frame of mind?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
No. The frame's broken.
[ Goes up to the window in alcove, L., and takes in a large American flag which is supposed to be hanging over window sill. Enter John from study, R.2.E. ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Phyllis, was it you I saw in the conservatory just now?

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: I spoke to you, but you didn't answer.

sp.speaker: Phyl.
sp.stage: Rising and taking flowers from top of piano where she has placed them
sp.p:
I was so intent on what I was doing that I didn't hear you.
[ Crosses to John ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
I'm glad to see you so contented — your life so peaceful. It is a solace to us all. Go, finish your wreath.
[ Exit Phyllis, L.2.E. ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Hello, brother John, I have something to communicate to you.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Indeed. What is it?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: It's off.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: What is off?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Mr. Robinson. I mean our engagement; tell you all about it tonight.
[ Crossing, R. ]
I wouldn't marry Alexander Robinson if there were nobody left in the world but — Fijis.
[ Throws flag on sofa, R., and exit upstairs, R.3.E. ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: I suppose I shall have a call from Alec. Mother, tell me about Ann.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Strange. Ann's first words after I kissed her were, "Tell me about John."

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Mother, since she went away, as the days have gone by, I have missed her from her accustomed place. The world has seemed different to me. My work has been harder. Even the old rectory became gloomy without her. But now that she has come back again — O Mother, even you do not know what she has been to me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: My boy, because your mother cannot see, do you think all things are hidden from her?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: In every thought of my life, I have somehow placed you and her together.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: While we have many friends, we have but one mother, and there is only one besides our mother who can share a confidence like her.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
True.
[ Music ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.stage: Rises; starts to go, R.2.E., turns and comes down to John
sp.p:
You see at last what I have known all along — that between you and Ann the feeling is not — friendship.
[ Exit, R.2.E. ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
No, mother. Great as my love was for that poor child, above and beyond it there has been a love not unknown — only misunderstood. But after what has passed between us, would she understand? Between us now there can be only friendship.
[ Exit, L.2.E. Enter Bess down steps, R.3.E., with a large package ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
I saw him coming up the street.
[ Places package on sofa, R. ]
Now, Mr. Robinson, I'll make you think you're on a transatlantic steamer, with an iceberg very near you. Here he comes. I must compose myself. I'll pretend to be happy.
[ Crossing to piano, R. ]
Of course there's no pretense about it, when I am happy.
[ With broken voice ]
Very, very h — happy.
[ Singing song from "Mikado," "I am happy, oh, so happy, always laughing, nectar quaffing," etc. Enter Alec, R.C., dressed as a private of Judge Knox's regiment. He also carries a package. He stands on the threshold ]

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Miss Van Buren.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: "I am happy — oh, so happy!"

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Miss Van Buren.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Oh — Mr. Robinson. Pardon me, I was so occupied with my music. Will you walk in?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
Thank you.
[ Coming down to L. Pause ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Did you call to see my brother John or angel?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: I called to see you.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: Crossing to R.C., sitting on sofa. Formally
sp.p: Oh! Be seated!

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
You are very kind.
[ Sits awkwardly on edge of chair, holding package on his knee ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Shall I ring for a messenger to put your package on the table?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
Thank you.
[ Coming down to L. Pause ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Very fine weather we are having.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
Very.
[ Short, awkward pause ]
Made the marching very pleasant today.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Did you parade with the regiment today?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Of course. Didn't you see me?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: With a dignified shake of her head ]
sp.p:
No.
[ Alec appears crushed ]
As you remarked that you came to see me, will you kindly state the purpose of this interview?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: I should have called this morning, only I was obliged to take my place in the ranks.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: In the ranks — yes.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: If I am only in the ranks, it is because —

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: When Judge Knox married your aunt, he put you there.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: I am proud to acknowledge Judge Knox as my colonel. There are worse soldiers than Uncle Pete.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Much worse.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
Miss Van Buren, your joking is ill-timed.
[ Rising ]
We will conclude this interview.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
The sooner, the quicker —
[ Rising ]
I mean, the better.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.stage: Placing his bundle on the table ]
sp.p: I came to return your presents. They are in that box.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: Up, taking her package and placing it on table
sp.p: This bundle contains yours. I had intended sending it. If you care to open the bundle and count them, you will find them all there. The only regret is that it is out of my power to return the Huyler's candy and the ice-cream sodas with which you have favored me.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Don't mention them. They are counterbalanced by the silk handkerchiefs which you have embroidered for me, and which, I am sorry to say, have been lost in the wash.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Your letters are there. You may need them again. They will spare you the pain of composing. I couldn't find your last. When I do, I will mail it to you. It must have been mislaid.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.stage: Pointing to portion of envelope sticking out of the bosom of her dress
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Oh! It must have slipped there — by accident.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: I thought I recognized my envelope. That's my color.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Crushed strawberry. How fitting!

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
Now that this painful interview is over, I will take my leave.
[ Going up, R., with hat ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: Crossing, R., and seating herself at piano
sp.p: I'm so happy — oh, so happy.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Of course you are aware that you are all wrong.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Excuse me, I am aware of no such thing. The fault is all on your side.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
I hope I am too much of a soldier to contradict a lady.
[ Goes C. and puts helmet on chair ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: It's a pity you didn't have on your uniform last night when the difficulty happened.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: There's sure to be a row between somebody whenever Mrs. Homer G. Putnam has private theatricals for her waifs. You had no right to stand at the side with Jack Dexter and laugh at me going through my scene in "As You Like It."

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Jack Dexter asked me if I didn't think it was ridiculous for Mrs. Putnam to cast you for Charles, the Wrestler. When I saw you in that close-fitting costume, I couldn't help laughing. Everybody laughed.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
Jack Dexter thought it was ridiculous, did he? Why didn't they get someone else to play the part? I'm black and blue already from the rehearsals. It may be Shakespeare's conception of the part to have Orlando throw the wrestler. I haven't said anything. But you just wait till the night of the performance. I'll make Jack Dexter sorry he ever played Orlando.
[ Starting upstage ]
Good-bye.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: Unconsciously picks up a corner of the flag, swinging it to and fro nervously
sp.p:
I hope, although we are about to part —
[ With effort ]
forever — that you will do nothing rash.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.stage: Taking up the other corner of the flag and swinging it nervously
sp.p: Oh, I don't care what becomes of me now. Nothing would please me better than for a war to break out tonight and me to be ordered to the front.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: But — you might get shot.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Oh, yes. Five or six bullets in me now wouldn't make much difference.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Although you are nothing to me any longer, I shouldn't like to hear of such an accident happening to you.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
I suppose, when the tidings came, you would go to the piano and sing
[ Singing in broken voice ]
"I'm so happy — oh, so happy."

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: N — n — no, I wouldn't, Alec.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Y — y — yes, you would, Bess.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: Crossing, L., still retaining end of flag
sp.p: You see if I will.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.stage: Starting to go upstage, still retaining end of flag
sp.p: Farewell, Miss Van Buren.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: You seem to be in a terrible hurry to go, Mr. Robinson.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: I don't think this agony is good for us.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.stage: Getting up to sofa, R.C., sniffling ]
sp.p: No —

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: One last word. If you are ever in need and want a friend, come to me.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: O Alec, you are so noble!

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: G — good — bye.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
Another last word. When I find somebody else to take your place —
[ Bess begins to cry ]
though I may give her my hand, my heart belongs to you.
[ Bess puts her head on Alec's shoulder, sobbing. During the above, they have gradually enveloped themselves in the flag. In their efforts to wipe away their tears with the corners of the flag, they bring it over their heads and sit precipitately upon the sofa, entirely concealed under the folds of the flag. Enter Judge Knox, R.C., dressed as a colonel of the National Guard ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
Is my wife here? She promised to come with a carriage and take me home — and my wife never forgets.
[ Absently places his helmet on Alec's head and comes down, C. Bess and Alec push sofa back ]
Cruger never forgets me, either. I met Cruger today and he indulged in one of his Stock Exchange jokes. He said if my horse and I were done in bronze, we'd make a splendid equestrian statue for the Old Ladies' Home.
[ Crossing, R. ]
I'll get even with Cruger for that yet.
[ Goes to R.2.E. ]
Ah, there she is.
[ Alec and Bess, still enveloped in the flag, rise with the Judge's helmet on top of them, and cross the room to the alcove, sitting in the rocking-chair ]
My heart fairly flutters at the sight of her. Coming, sweetheart.
[ Turns to get his helmet and is amazed at finding it gone. Looks around room ]
I could have sworn I left my hat there.
[ Seeing it in alcove, startled ]
How the devil did it get up there?
[ Alec and Bess rock violently, the Judge watching the movement, dumbfounded ]
Eh?
[ Goes R. and calls ]
Sweetheart! Sweetheart!
[ Enter, R.2.E., Mrs. Knox, formerly Mrs. De Peyster, followed by Mrs. Van Buren ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. K.
sp.p: Peter, dear, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Look into my eyes. Are my pupils dilated? Do you notice any incipient traces of insanity about me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. K.
sp.p: Why, Peter!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
I placed my hat there. Then I found it there, and saw it move there.
[ Bess and Alec rock again ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. K.
sp.p:
Good gracious! There's something under the flag.
[ Judge goes up, C., throws back the top of the flag, discovering Alec and Bess in the act of kissing, unconscious of everything around them. Bess gives a slight cry. They rise quickly and stand with flag partially around them ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: There are two somethings.

sp.speaker: Mrs. K.
sp.p: Alec.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: We claim the protection of our country's flag.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: What are you doing, Bess?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Standing by the flag, angel.

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: We were only looking for a quiet spot.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Well, I hope you'll find it soon — for your methods are not only original, but decidedly outré.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Please excuse us. We didn't hear anybody come in.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Then you have patched up your little difficulty?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Yes, we are in the same frame again.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
And a very pretty chromo you make.
[ Bess comes to Mrs. Van Buren ]
Young man, does your financial condition warrant your assuming the responsibility of paying this young woman's board bills, for the balance of the term of your natural existence?

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p: Now, Uncle Pete, don't joke; I don't like jokes.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Mrs. K.
sp.p: Quite true, Peter, Alec could never bear to receive or play a joke.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
I think, sweetheart, that you do our nephew a great injustice. I think that, with his sense of humor, he would not be averse to a joke — if it were a corking good one.
[ Alec laughs. Bess starts to take package from table ]

sp.speaker: Alec .
sp.p:
I'll carry them, Bess.
[ Going upstairs, R.3.E., with package ]
I mean to carry your burdens all through life.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Alec, I'll sort all your letters over again and tie them all up with fresh ribbon.
[ Exeunt Bess and Alec, R.3.E., upstairs ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Judge, did you have a hard day's march?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: A hard day's ride. They sent me a car horse to parade on. Every time my sword clanked, he thought it was the car bell, and stopped. Nothing could induce him to go on but clanking it again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. K.
sp.p: I hope, darling, you were in no danger on such an animal.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Your darling hasn't been so shaken up since he went to Chicago on the B. &.mp; O. The next time I parade, I'll go down to Chambers Street and get a horse out of a harness store.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Let me get you a cup of tea, judge. It will refresh you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. K.
sp.p: Yes, Peter, do. Nothing restores the tissue like tea.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
Very well. My four hours on that Arabian steed caused a desire for something soothing.
[ Aside ]
I'll stand up and take a little tea.

sp.speaker: Mrs. K.
sp.p: I'll go with you, dear. I know just how he likes it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: One year yesterday since you were married.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: I'd like to begin with yesterday and live it backward. You don't mind a couple of old spoons, do you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Van B.
sp.p: Old spoons? No. It is a part of the family silver that we ought never to permit to grow tarnished.

sp.speaker: Mrs. K.
sp.p: Our occasional little rubs only serve to make brighter this piece of precious metal.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
Oh, go along now!
[ To Mrs. Van Buren ]
There is only one thing that mars our otherwise harmonious career.

sp.speaker: Mrs. K.
sp.p: Indeed, what is that, dear?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
That's the parrot. I am awakened every morning by that parrot's screaming, "De Peyster, De Peyster, it's time to get up!" Good heavens! Suppose De Peyster should get up?
[ Mrs. Knox is much shocked ]
My dear, I wish you would teach that bird that I am not De Peyster.
[ Enter Jasper, R.2.E. Lights a piano lamp, gets flag, puts sofa downstage, lights three lamps in alcove, and exit, L.2.E. ]

sp.speaker: Mrs. K.
sp.p: Very well, Peter. Polly shall go into another room.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
If it doesn't, I'll give Polly a powder and turn Polly into a bird of Paradise.
[ Exeunt Mrs. Van Buren and Mrs. Knox, R.2.E. Enter John, L.2.E. ]
O John, have you seen Ann?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Not yet.

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: I'm glad of that. I want to ask your help in a matter that concerns her deeply. I'm her godfather, you know, and ever since she was a little child, she has poured out her troubles to me. Now I've discovered that she's in love.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Ann!

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Cupid has fired into her heart everything that he had — quiver and all. I've had some experience myself, and I know what I'm talking about.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Who is it Ann loves?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: I prefer to keep his name to myself for the present. She went away on his account — some misunderstanding.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Misunderstanding?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: Now, of course, John, there's nothing that would please you and me so much as to see Ann happily married.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: She would be happy with him?

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p:
Oh, the man loves her.
[ John turns away slightly ]
I never felt so positive of it as I do at the present moment.
[ Crosses to R. ]
Now you talk to her, John — make her tell you the truth — the whole truth. I think you'll marry her soon.
[ Music. Exit, R.2.E. ]

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Ann has given her love to someone. She will become a wife. Well, she will be happy. And her husband — whoever he may be, he must be happy in her love. O Ann, in this the bitterest loss of my life, I shall be without your help. I must suffer alone.
[ He falls into chair, his head upon his arms on the table. Ann, who has passed the window on the landing, is coming down the steps, R.3.E. Then she descends ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: John!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.stage: Starts, rises, and takes her hands ]
sp.p: Ann! Ann!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
I'm — I'm glad to see you, John.
[ Pressing her hand to her face for a moment as though a little faint ]
I declare, the happiness of being home again is harder to withstand than the sorrow of parting. John, I just passed the old window seat where we used to sit and read together, and, I know you'll think me foolish, John, but before coming down to you, I sat there and had a good cry.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Ah! Then you were glad to get back to the old rectory, weren't you?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Glad! Why, just now I stole into the house on purpose that nobody might know I was here, so I could go to every familiar nook and corner and say "How de do" to them all, after being away from them so long.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: They have missed you.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.stage: Sitting on chair, L. of table
sp.p: And I have missed them. Not a day went by — not an hour, that my thoughts didn't turn from the scenes through which I was passing to the old rectory of St. Mildred's — and my heart never failed to follow my thought. Ah, John, it is over a year since I said good-bye to the dear old place.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Ann, you went away with trouble at your heart of which you told me nothing.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: John.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: I have learned it from others.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Learned what?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: That you went away because of a misunderstanding between you and someone you love. Let me hear it from your own lips, that I may be sure.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: I — I — cannot speak of it to you.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: I may be able to help you.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: My love is hopeless.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Then there is someone that you love?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Who loves you?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: You went away to avoid him?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: You love him so much?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: More than he will ever know.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Ann, do you think I will let a misunderstanding keep you away from the man you love when I know that he loves you? Judge Knox told me. He told me to come to you.
[ Earnestly ]
And do you think he would let me speak to you unless he were sure?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: I — I don't know. I never in my life was quite so perplexed.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Ann, it was in this very room, over this table, just as we are now, that I told you of a love that seemed to promise happiness. Don't shut me out of your happiness. Let me be to you now what you were then to me. Do you remember when we read together the story of David Copperfield? How the friendship between Agnes and David hid from them their love for each other?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Not from Agnes.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: True. It was only David who was deceived. And, like him, I have been blind. My love for Phyllis was like David's love for Dora. With that love I still had the friendship and sympathy of one who was to me as a sister. When Phyllis passed out of my life, I still had that friendship and sympathy and I could endure. It was only when Agnes was taken away from me that I realized what she had been to me.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Then why not go to her and tell her?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: It is too late.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: So David thought when he spoke to Agnes.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: But the woman I love loves someone else.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Are you sure?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Yes, Ann, for it is you.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: John!

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: This should never have passed my lips, did I not wish you to know how dear your happiness is to me. Tell me your secret as I have told you mine.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: O John, spare me; I am not myself.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: But you will tell me? You will let me help you?

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: You do help me, John. Have you forgotten what the feelings of Agnes were for David? When he questioned her about the man she loved, he found it was himself.

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Ann!

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: Now do you know why I had to go away?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Ann — Ann — do you love me?
[ Chimes ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
Yes.
[ They embrace. Enter Judge Knox, R.2.E. Ann goes L. ]

sp.speaker: Judge .
sp.p: John, did she tell you?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p:
Yes.
[ Enter Mrs. Van Buren and Mrs. Knox, R.2.E. Judge speaks apart with Mrs. Knox and Mrs. Van Buren. Bess runs on, R.3.E., followed by Alec. Betts enters, R.C. Phyllis enters, L.2.E., with the wreath of flowers, which she gives to Betts; Betts goes up, C. Phyllis goes into alcove and takes the lamp from the mantel and places it in window ]

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Brother John, it's on again for keeps.
[ Bess and Alec, on stairs, R.U.E., talk confidentially. John comes down toward Ann, L.C. ]

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p: John, shall I tell you my secret now?

sp.speaker: John .
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ann .
sp.p:
I have loved you all my life.
[ Bess on the landing with Alec. Judge and Mrs. Knox watching John and Ann, the Judge speaking of them to Mrs. Van Buren, who listens, pleased. Betts has left Phyllis and stands with the wreath on the threshold at the back, to take his departure. Phyllis placed the lamp used in Act I and Act III on the table in the alcove and is in the act of lighting it as the chimes ring out and the curtain slowly descends ]
